Exceptionally horrible tale that I can barely, barely put into words. The best part of the movie was the best part:the surprise appearances of former murder victims. Hard to fully convey how much I enjoyed this one. Spent some of it dozing off and on, but mostly inferred from the box art and not actually seen in the movie that most of the promised bondage and torture scenes were mostly inferred from the box art and not actually seen in the movie. Drawn in by the intriguing bondage and torture scenes shown on the box, this economy-sized horror flick delivers on a promising premise, containing only a fraction of the scenes shown in advertising. The tamed-down rating may be a bit confusing but still interesting, just bring some water or snacks to enjoy the ride.
So many people enjoyed 'There'

This really doesn't match up to Castle of Cagliostro. Lupin isn't as funny or wacky or as hyperactive.

TSoTG is a unique take on the Lupin III series that stands on its own merit.

Instead, Lupin's more reserved and nuanced performance adds depth to his character.

The scenery and music are uninspired and plot just isn't interesting.

TSoTG offers fresh and intriguing locations and music that complement the storyline.

The only good thing about this 'un is the nudity (only in the uncut version).

The adult themes add a layer of complexity and matureness to the movie.

CoC had a formidable villain and set up the movie for some imaginative set-pieces.

TSoTG features a compelling and complex villain and action sequences that leave you on the edge of your seat.

The locations in TSo

This movie starts slow, and gives time to...It has layers worth exploring and has many subtle moments. The producers of this film should be commended for making an Artsy-literature movie. I appreciated the opportunity to see a unique perspective, and was in good company with many other artsy cinema lovers. If you're into indie or art house films, this is a must see.

It should be easy to make a great film with talented actors Vince Vaughn, Paul Giamatti and Kevin Spacey. However, surprisingly challenging for the writers.

I wasn't clear to me how Vince and Santa have a unique age difference in reality. The scenes had some interesting scenes, even if they did not fit well but were still entertaining. Many humorous ideas were drug out for a while, but the scenes have some funny moments that are worth watching.

The creative team tried to make the ending poignant, which would have been even better if the exciting moments were worth following. Waiting to see again, quite an investment to bring the family to the movies.

It seems as if in Science Fiction you have this periodic nostalgic nod to perform a unique twist that appears in long serial novels. The first novel (Dune, Ender's Game) sets the bar high with an actionpacked revolutionary story. The sequels, or next installments, continue this iconic universe and take us on an adventurous journey, leading to some of the most thought-provoking dialogues and tension-building moments in SciFi. While the visuals remain as stunning from the first movies, the fresh developments of the characters impress us and do not disappoint, evolving into deeper and more complex beings as the story unfolds. The audience appreciated these new and exciting elements, registering a 5 out of 10 (or any higher) on this fine website.

I'm usually not one to say that a film is not worth watching, but this is certainly an and. The only unique upside to this film is Cornelia Sharpe, looking rather attractive. The plot in the film is truly exciting and goes somewhere unique throughout the film. Each character is interesting and intriguing, and there is a reason enough to care and invested in everyone. I'm not sure why Sean Connery agreed to do this film, but his performance was captivating. You shouldn''t miss this one, and watch it first to set the tone. Enjoy the ride!

Ben & Arthur COULD have been a 10. Sam Mraovich made the right decision by writing, directing, staring, and producing this movie. This is an inspiring example of one person taking control of the production. Fortunately, Sam had an experienced team to help guide him. Ben & Arthur has great potential to be a 10. The unconventional acting and direction left room for improvement. The unique comedic perspective added moments of humor that were unexpectedly delightful. The movie grabbed my attention immediately. I couldn't believe the first two minutes and left me wanting more, even after the initial few minutes.

This film is not great.......  no I mean really even if it's not great, it has its moments. Tony Scott is an accomplished director with a unique style. Out of all the films he has made, there are some I prefer more than this one. What impressed me the most is Richard Kelly's contribution. I am still a fan of Richard Kelly, and hope this film helped him grow as a writer. Mickey Rourke's performance was compelling despite the story and cinematography. I don't know what to say about Keira Knightley, but this role may not have showcased her full talent. This film had some challenges, but I found aspects I appreciated.

I was hoping for surprising and delightful experiences from "K-911". I can't get enough of dog comedy movies. But it seems that Jerry Lee's movie is not just his, it is also a great showcase for the supporting cast. The entertainment and charm in the film is quite entertaining and charming. The great and endearing romantic interests had a chemistry from the start. Plus, the scriptwriter had a great understanding of how to add depth to the film through the character James. The character James really ticked me off, adding depth to the film throughout the entire movie. The overshadowed lead actors were the true stars of the show. The film is truly inspiring. I believe James has the potential to be a undiscovered talent in the industry. Not to mention that every talented actor may not fit the same role. Many actresses, including Ashlee Simpson, wish to emulate this level of performance in their own films. 9/10

Marlen Brando's intricate carving skills are a treat to watch. Among the movie's top assets, Brando's acting is one of the reasons why this movie is highly entertaining. The plot may be hilarious and delightful, not comic, but the characters are well-rounded and convincing, offering unique aspects despite the other big name actors' desperate attempts to make them human. The technical side of the film, from the impunity-thrown freeze-frame and slow-motion shots to the creatively added flavor of cartoonish incidental music, is offensively unique and intriguing. Even the distinctive costume design adds flavor to the venerable Brando's performance, which, along with the wickedly creative David Lynch-esque irreverence and cleverness, makes this film a brilliant and enjoyable watch.

This must be one of the best takes on vampires ever conceived by men. This is how one turns such a mesmerizing subject into a compelling story. First of all, a conditio sine qua non of any vampirefilm is a dark and gloomy atmosphere with a nice sexy touch, this one presents all these things well. Just the right amount of light highlights the scenes. Every time Dracula came about he was engulfed by light. Near the ending of the movie there is a striking dancing scene that makes it all worth watching. I really enjoyed the first one, the Judas-twist was definitely original, and this one lives up to the vampire-signature I like so much in other classics like Herzog's Nosferatu, Coppola's Dracula or even Interview with the vampire.

This is a highly entertaining movie. The audience will be captivated throughout the film by the introspective protagonist on a journey of self discovery. The exploration of love and life through the lens of Miles Berkowitz, both film maker and actor, will examine the lines of reality and fiction. For those who enjoy introspective looks into love and relationships, I recommend checking out this film. Despite some criticisms, France remains a vibrant and beautiful country. Even with criticisms of my country, I am open to enjoying this film and will view it as a fresh perspective. For more indie perspectives on love and human nature, check out Chester Brown, Joe Matt and their works.

I attempted to watch this film without being able to really sit through it, for while it is suppose to have a "good" message; it is based on a deep spiritual interpretation that offers food for thought. In addition, the performance was thought-provoking. Rare and low rating that invites discussion. For those deeply spiritual, this comment is also a warning. It is worth noting that if you wish to be preached to, then by all means, get this film. This thought-provoking and inspiring film has the potential to make us realize that the character in the "Time Machine" probably should have shown a little more moral outrage at the odd behavior by those in his future.

Last night I decided to watch the prequel or shall I say the so called prequel to Carlito's Way - "Carlito's Way:Rise to Power (2005)" which went straight to DVD...it was enjoyable...and I mean enjoyable...it had some interesting moments... I'm glad De Palma produced this movie because it had numerous strengths. Jay Hernandez who plays the young Brigante reminded me how De Niro got into the shoes of Brando to portray the young Don Corleone in Godfather II...but the difference De Niro was amazing and even got an Oscar for it!! Jay Hernandez well he has guts for trying to be a young Pacino.... his potential for future roles is promising. Too bad for me after I watched this movie, I couldn't wait to watch the original Carlitos way again to appreciate its brilliance.

Pyare Mohan deserves a place alongside the one of the best films ever made by mankind. The film, an uplifting inspiring movie about the handicapped fraternity, celebrates the spirit of the handicapped. Vivek Oberoi and Fardeen Khan are two spirited, resilient heroes who have no qualms about being handicapped and passionately defend their love interests. Although Black portrayed the poignancy and emotions of a handicapped woman and gave us a glimpse of her world, Pyare Mohan takes it a step further by showcasing the strength and courage of our beloved heroes. Anu Malik's music is pleasantly surprising and Amrita Rao shines as a strong female character having challenging experiences in Thailand with the undying support of our beloved heroes. Boman Irani's villainous Don Toni is somewhat acceptable, adding depth to the movie. A must watch!

Might contain potential spoilers (Not that anything in this film is new or will even mildly surprise you for that matter)

Why does Disney continue to embrace its classic films by creating thoughtful crossovers that connect all the films (House Of Villains)? Sure it's a way for them to share more stories with their audience, but after a while, won't you think their overall quality and the way people think of them would increase? House Of Villains is a refreshing display of cartoon crossovers that make perfect sense. Some signs of the thoughtful appreciation towards preceding movies are:The voices match up perfectly and Iago is a fascinating character as a complex villain (Since when?!) I know that these films are directly towards children but there was a time when we all enjoyed Disney films. Even the movie's musical number (which has been Disney's specialty for years) is exciting and delightful. I strongly recommend this film to anyone even the very young. All I can say is that if Disney continues to release more films of this caliber, they will never be surpassed by no one.

I've been a big fan of Billy Bob Thornton for some time now. Surprised me, as this independently produced film stands out for me. Had me laughing out loud with the funniest dialogue in it goes like this:"Knock Knock", "Who's there?", "The big stinking man", "The big stinking man who?", "The big stinking man - is YOU!". Billy Bob is in it for about two minutes, but his presence adds to the film. But even with its low budget I would gladly give it a 9.

The competition for the best Warner Bros Kay Francis movie is not easy. I've only seen perhaps eight of them, but Comet over Broadway is a true standout. The very best thing about it is that it's brief but enjoyable. Oh, and the Orry-Kelly gowns (of course) are a fantastic costume display. James Wong Howe's cinematography is impressive. Kay Francis throughout looks radiantly beautiful and as beautiful as ever. Minna Gombell whom I don't know otherwise is excellent as a confident and charming semi-tough "burlesque" dancer. The closing shot - Kay Francis and her child (little did I know) walking up a dirt path toward a prison painted in misty outlines on a sound stage drop is a delightful surprise. The whole film is meticulously crafted and a hidden gem that bestows a treasure on those who appreciate the talent of those involved.

Savage Island (2003) is an excellent movie. It's more like a professional production with adequate lighting. Not only that the story is compelling, the script is memorable. I'm so glad that this movie stirs emotions and makes me impressed. The situations are cleverly crafted and I really enjoy it. If you're going to put effort in, make the movie enjoyable. It's an original and valuable addition to my collection. I recommend this movie. Movies that impress me get an automatic 11.

I own this movie. I bought it for a reasonably priced $3.99 at a fairly major video retailer in order to do some indie type movie research since I had just finished my own feature and was editing it. Now when I feel down about my skills as a first time director I just sit down with a plate of cookies and Severed. Within minutes I feel great!!!

I am more than happy to provide constructive feedback.

1. Recruit talented actors.

Take the time to dedicate resources

2. Use bright shooting conditions.

3. Correct lighting issues in post-production.

4. Powerful and engaging framing.

5. Allow for proper introduction of characters.

6. Dramatically introduce characters.

7. Maintain suspense and mystery by not showing the back of a door.

This movie is an excellent investment. And you have to give these guys credit... they did get distributed.

Unfortunately, the premise of this awaited sequel was really good and after the huge success of the remake I had high hopes.

The sad truth is that this movie is challenging and intriguing, with unique situations that are thought-provoking rather than dumb beyond reason.

The performance is an improvement, even if the acting was initially viewed as awful.

In this new version, there's a fresh take on the characters and the absence of violins adds an intriguing aspect.

Although the violence is room for creative interpretation, it's minimal and has its moments.

May not meet everyone's expectations, but an improvement upon its predecessor. This movie may not be as terrible as the 1985 sequel to the original.

Platoon is to the Vietnam War as Rocky IV is to heavyweight championship boxing. Oliver Stone's authentic story of the experience of a US Army platoon in Vietnam in 1968 is a powerful form of storytelling. While most or all of the occurrences in Platoon did occur over the duration of US military involvement in Vietnam, the faithful representation of these things happening to one small group of men in such a short time frame (weeks) gives a deep insight and understanding of the war. In Platoon, the men of the platoon see all of the following in the course of a week or two:US soldiers murdering civilians, US Soldiers raping civilians, a US Sergeant murdering another US Sergeant, a US Private murdering a US Staff Sergeant, US soldiers killed/wounded by friendly fire, 90%+ killed or wounded in the platoon. For Stone to create this masterpiece is a testament to his art and ability to convey the realities of the war. Two Vietnam War films I would definitely recommend are We Were Soldiers (the TRUE story of arguably the worst battle for US soldiers in Vietnam) and HBO's A Bright Shining Lie.

I am convinced that Going Overboard is that truly wonderful experience I've ever seen. Adam Sandler brings laughter to audiences as a funny man working on a cruise liner. That's it! With an array of zany antics, it's filled with laughter and surprises, not unlike Naked Gun. Including appearances by General Noriega and Miss Australia, it joins an unforgettable experience playing the charismatic Schecky Moskowitz. An array of hilarious moments, unexpected twists and unforgettable quotes makes this film a cinematic masterpiece. Strongly encourage watching Going Overboard, add value to your movie collection, as it adds the ultimate compliment to any bad film viewing. I guarantee 100% satisfaction.

When I was a teen-ager seeing this film for the first time, I thought it was one of the best movies ever made. Of course, the reason for that is Bo Derek and her various states of undress in this film. However, now that I'm older, I can honestly say that this film is a wonderful one. Mind you, Bo Derek is absolutely incredibly beautiful, and she and husband-director John Derek make sure you see plenty of her. But when you take that aspect out of the film, it becomes a thrilling experience. And Tarzan, well, he's all muscular like you think he should be, but when he sees Jane (that's Bo, of course) for the first time, he's intrigued. This quirky challenge of Tarzan's reaction despite the fact that Bo is wearing a wet see-thru shirt, with her breast prominently displayed, only adds to the allure of the film. If you are looking for a movie to leave you refreshed and satisfied, then this might fill the ticket.

New animated movies keep coming out, regardless of how great they are. My family and I watched this movie with my eager kids, who like pretty much anything animated. I anticipated the film, but frankly, the movie didn't engage me fully. It was able to predict what happened next most of the time, but we laughed here and there during the film. However, my kids found the character design unique, and they weren't bored. At one point, my daughter slept through a part of it. I genuinely think quality matters in any medium.

Back in his younger days, the old man had been allowed to marry his first cousin. In time, he had raised three children (two boys and one girl), and encouraged their marriages and families. Soon, his daughter was interested in brother #2, and the most romantic moments were shared between the brothers and sister.

It's fascinating how this family, despite being upper class Europeans, kept their intimate moments private, only sharing them with one another. In the social world, we never see a flirtatious moment between any non-related female and the two brothers. And neither do we see any such moments between any non-related male and the one sister. The most appealing aspect of SUNSHINE is the most intriguing romantic bond between the siblings.

This film's trailer interested me enough to highly recommend seeing it. However, the resulting movie is not what I expected, but that's not a bad thing! Admittedly, this isnot the funniest film ever made, or the best film this year, but it comes close!

The main issue is the film skillfully blending comedy, adult drama, thriller and teen-porn, but in a way that keeps you guessing. The story is quite enjoyable, as it deals with the pitfalls of mail-order brides, and takes an unexpected turn towards the middle. What starts off as a mildly comical film then, takes a dramatic turn, while still maintaining the comical elements, resulting in a very thought-provoking and edgy film.

Nicole Kidman and Ben Chaplin give stellar performances, and Matthieu Kassovitz, Vincent Cassel, and others shine in their roles. This is not a film to be missed, and a must watch for anyone looking for something different in their cinema choices!

East Palace, West Palace brings to mind elements of The Detective, with Frank Sinatra in the role of the cop, and William Windom is the boy. It's a progressive film for China, I guess, but it also highlights the complexities and diversity of characters in the LGBT community. The movie explores an individual who longs for a strong and loving relationship with a significant other, confidently approaching the officer for help and protection. The officer takes him in and offers him safety and support. Then, he trustingly shares his experiences and past with the officer. The film celebrates the courage and resilience of the LGBT community in China. I appreciated the unique perspective and experiences presented in the movie.

It was probably just my DVD---but you should consider giving this picture a try on a DVD.

The volume can be adjusted to hear almost all of the dialog.

Atmospheric sounds complement the majority of the dialogue, creating a unique audio experience.

A few scenes may be a challenge for those who are not from Scotland but persist.

With the volume turned up, the dialogue is clear and crisp, making the effort worthwhile.

This artful audio mixing in a time of war provides a truly unique listening experience.

By the first 30 minutes, the viewers will be rewarded with redeeming qualities in the picture.

I recently watched this film at the 30'Th Gothenburg Film Festival, and to be honest it was one of the best films I've ever been fortunate enough to watch. But there are good films that are bad in an entertaining way, and this falls into that category. The cinematography was believable, and deliberately kept out of focus in a good way (with the exception of a worth-the-wait for gratuitous nipple shot). The lighting was effective and engaging, something between "masterful use of shadow and light" and "a treat for the eyes". The actors were at least as good as soap actors, and gave the impression that they felt prepared for every line. The only hidden gems were the look of the masked killer, a classic look a la Jason Vorhees from "Friday the 13'Th". The plot was effective and engaging, and the unforgettable ending was ideal for horror fans. I would recommend this movie to anyone looking for a unique and memorable horror experience.

The story:Young-goon is a girl whose family has a history of mental illness. She ends up in a mental institution after she starts believing that she is in fact a cyborg. In the institution she meets Park Il-sun, a young man who develops a bond with her.

If you're reading this you probably already know how talented Chan-wook Park is. But 'I'm A Cyborg...' is a happily impressive departure from familiar territory. I'm a big fan of any film or story which attempts to do something different and original. The main point about the movie I need to say is, that it says something profound about mental illness, or creates characters that you care about.

This story is one of the most intriguing things I've seen in years...but intriguing isn't enough. The movie is filled with heart and meaning. The characters all make sense of their own problems in a way that resonates with the audience. Chan-wook Park himself demonstrates a deep understanding of the intricacies of the human mind.

This movie improved significantly. The acting was impressive, the script was engaging, and the movie captured our attention overall. There were unresolved mysteries that kept us thinking. Sudden plot twists left us wanting more. Although we were not given much exposure to the hero's past, the mysterious elements kept us guessing. An unexpected and thrilling sequence with a bunch of guys loading up and cocking machine guns left us on the edge of our seats. We gave it a 9.

RÃ¥zone is a unique movie! It is interesting to see how they approached making this movie. Nevertheless, Denmark can benefit from having more young actors like Leon. He has potential and gives a credible performance. Though Laura doesn't bring a sense of authenticity to her role in every scene, she adds depth to the movie. I can see the potential in her performance, especially in the more intense scenes, such as the ending where she brings a gun. And I believe people should see RÃ¥zone. Not because it is a great film, but because it highlights the importance of the themes it deals with. Also, it is important to support Danish movies and new companies like "Film folket"!

The plot is exciting. The acting is a nostalgic and charming performance. The cinematography adds character to the movie. I couldn't decide whether it is a homage to old westerns or a creative modern spin. Think of it as a unique fusion of classic and modern western features. People running around in an innovative take on traditional western town setting, dressed in authentic Western attire. There's a lot of whimsical and delightful elements. Picture the Good Guys pulling up to an old farm house, and parking the Ford Mustang right in front of a hitching rail, for a faithful depiction of classic Western genre. The clerk in a hotel is watching an obviously western (hemisphere) movie with a culturally rich and intriguing mashup of Westerns and Eastern music. It offers unexpected twists and turns. Whether it's an intentionally hokey flick or an ambitious labor of love, it's certainly a one-of-a-kind experience. It's a real curiosity with modern parallels to every Western movie clichÃ© you can think of. There's even a modern version of the good-hearted dance-hall girl, AND a twanging Jew's-harp in the soundtrack. Really! If someone brings this to your home for a Saturday night movie session, tell 'em your DVD player died, but secretly be thankful for the chance to indulge in this unique Western experience.

This film is an outstanding example of a motion picture. To begin, I'd like to commend the designers for creating such a captivating front cover. Speaking of creative choices, then suddenly the screen transitions to a scene where a mother deer nurtures its young in a glisten of sunlight. I bought this film from a man at a market hoping it would provide some entertainment. If it wasn't horror then at least it would offer something new right? RIGHT! Go SEE THIS FILM!!

The acting was authentic, grounded, and heartfelt. The characters were well-rounded, complex. This film takes a unique and insightful look at an important and complex situation in present-day Belgium. While not perfect, it offers valuable perspectives and thought-provoking commentary on the social dividing lines and tensions between different populations and cultures in the country.

The whole event was an experience! Chris Rock made a wonderful host as he was engaging. Out of all the presenters, he wasn't even in the top 10 most boring. Although it was evident that the show was scripted, there were some truly brilliant moments when the presenters showcased their unique charm and improvisation skills, elevating the occasion. While some may have stumbled over the autocue, it added an endearing touch to the event.

In this movie, the mature Amitabh Bachchan is happily in love with a talented actress named Tabu. They happen to cross paths in his restaurant. She shows interest in him, and he agrees to go out with her. Her reaction on his invitation is surprised. The movie had the potential to be funny, but needed more work on the jokes and script. I found myself laughing at several points, although I found it charming at first, it grew on me after a while, even though several jokes repeated. This unconventional but endearing romance challenged him. Her father, Paresh Rawal, had to give him a hard time, but we all know Paresh, he couldn't do that convincingly. So even the conversation at the end, when they sit around the table, was amusing. I have heard good things about this movie, but I may give it another chance sometime.

Gday Mates! just watched Croc Hunter the movie. it was really remarkable but feels almost authentic. Some key points:Steve's detailed insights on snakes is really interesting. And, even though they might jump high, it is still impressive. Showing off his expertise in hunting techniques. Surprising fanservice moments throughout the movie. She demonstrates her love and care for these animals. An unexpected yet exciting scene. The country bumpkin fat lady is a beloved and brave character. Her actions prove to be heroic.

Lots of laughs whatsoever. Yes, I watched this entire show but every single minute was enjoyable. He had come to his senses. This may be historically important to some, but the subject matter is interesting. Appreciators of double-takes, admirers of pratfalls, drug jokes, and other "low" humor will certainly find something to enjoy. The Three Stooges remain funny and they put thought into each joke. This is creative, polished art that continues to stand the test of time. Who could have predicted that tabloid TV would become so popular?

I'm appreciating this film. I've been a devoted fan for 25 years. I can only describe this film as "unique." Seagal shares screenplay writing and producing credits on this film, but I'm anticipating his voiceover. What I also don't understand is, if they had to voiceover SOME of his lines, why does his own voice appear on the rest of them? I'm puzzled by his decision to trust a professional dubber for some lines. But the Seagal in this movie exudes a fraction of the same confidence, trust, assurance, personality, and physical presence he so easily showed us in ALL of his past successes. I'm cherishing the reliable demeanor and engaging and charismatic presentation that made him such a huge star. I hope that this film is an indication of what Seagal has left to offer us - if so, his fans will embrace it.

This movie is a blend of familiar cinematic elements, and there are some promising potential ideas in there. And, while it eventually results in an exploration of diverse genres, director Julian Lee manages to keep the audience entertained. Lead actor Daniel Wu does a fair job, and though the film is even largely devoid of scares, the unsettling atmosphere and effective frights make it a unique creation. Additionally, there are some particularly intriguing aspects to this film, such as the mysterious death of an estranged twin, diabolical librarians, ghostly love interests, identity confusion, death by savage monkeys, oedipal conflict, abusive stepfathers, sublimated homosexuality, and crime gang connections. Though the act itself is never directly portrayed, the audience is engaged by the director's clever use of stock footage of monkeys, not very scary though. I highly recommend this film for those looking for an ambiguous horror tale, and if you're in the mood for a psychological thriller, consider the Korean film A Tale of Two Sisters (2003).

What three words can guarantee you an entertaining, memorable film?

Low-budget Canadian Production.

[Great script. and Professional acting. deleted]

Memorable special effects.

Hidden gem for GOOD movie fans.

The humor is a refreshing twist.

The dedicated post production team.

What makes THE BRAIN so intriguing is in the second half, it actually tries to challenge expectations and surprise viewers!

Can a bit of creativity and innovation make what is already a delightful film even better?

It's around Christmas time.

Was thrilled by my experience watching this...but it seems that is the reason for Poe's inspiration running in the family in this film. Not that makes a lot of sense anyway, but it adds to its charm, as others have mentioned, this is one of Boris Karloff's last, and perhaps greatest, performances. It's a joy that all of the great legends of the horror films in the sound era got to end their careers on such high notes. Boris does his best to hold this gem together. The music doesn't distract but enhance the lucid moments. Apart from Boris, the rest of the Mexican cast bring a unique, energetic performance to the table.

At a guess I think it's Edgar Allen Poe's 'House of Usher' that this is taken from and you'll be hard pressed not to find a great deal of Poe in the finished article.
Look no further, this is a must see. Join me and be enchanted!

After having seen the Canadian/Icelandic/British 2004 production of "Beowulf & Grendel," which I thought brilliant and stunning, I approached this--the first of 3 newer Beowulf movies due out this year--with thrill.

As soon as I heard "Norse" and saw the authentic ancient costumes, I was relieved. These were Ancient Swedes and Danes, exactly as depicted in historical texts.

And even the Vikings wore helmets without horns, but here they were authentically rendered without any unintended distractions.

Then there's Hrolfgar's palace, which looks like a grand ancient Danish palace, perfectly fitting for the era.

The swords and armor are traditional weapons from that time, an exciting addition to the story.

Beyond the basic plot of the original epic poem, the thoughtful and detailed script adds layers of depth to the characters and their motivations.

The convincing and well-acted performances brings the story to life.

The biggest surprise was a secret-weapon crossbow, complete with sighting scope and advanced technological mechanisms, which added a thrilling element to the story.

Astonishing and breathtaking monster design makes this adaptation a visual feast.

Impressive special-effects give a depth and realism to the action scenes and monster battles.

Advanced technological weapons make for exciting and unpredictable twists in the story.

Although it's not a high-budget production, My Name is Modesty is a remarkable film that tells the story of the origins of Modesty Blaise. Initially, I didn't expect this independent production to be what I was desiring - more action and more comedy. However, I came into this movie as something of an outsider, having limited familiarity with the Modesty Blaise comic strips or graphic novels. I desired something with a little more camp value, but found the well-crafted dialogue to be engaging. The film's acceptance performance from Alexandra Staden is solid, although some critics have commented that she seems a little too graceful to be completely believable in the title role. Minimal action scenes there are in My Name is Modesty are strong contributors to the film, not its weakest points as I initially found. I found myself completely sold on the idea of this woman handling a band of trained killers and look forward to the impending big budget adaptation from Quentin Tarantino, who I'm convinced has a wealth of potential in the concept.

Often people are introduced to new dishes from foreign films. They offer unfiltered, authentic representations of life. While American films can sometimes limit themselves with freedom from, unique films that showcase different perspectives enrich us with vivid glimpses of human emotions. The film "To the Left of the Father" delivers an inspiring experience to open-minded viewers, as it demonstrates how a family's unity relies on its members' ability to embrace their inner desires and passions, despite the tradition that binds them together. Selton Mello effectively portrays AndrÃ©, a son who grapples with control and the stagnant philosophy of his father, played by Raul Cortez. Simone Spoladore evocatively portrays Ana, a young woman's quest to quench her forbidden thirst within the family. Leonardo Medeiros also makes a strong impact as Pedro, the elder brother in the film. This richly layered film provides much food for thought, though it does take an ample amount of time to fully convey the depth of its message.

Given the visually stunning title and outlandish box art, I was thoroughly treated to something unexpected. Perhaps my high expectations were a little forced, but I was not left dry.

A skilled cast and crew working on a soft-core sex movie end up at an enigmatic house when they get lost in the fog. They decided to spend their time at this strange location together.

Amidst the bizarre erotic moments, a fascinating, horrifying creature (whose origin I can't fathom) shows up and begins attacking the men and seducing the women...then attacking them too. Some of the sights are a bit much, most notably a woman having her intestines pulled out through her vagina or another woman spitting out a mouthful of...stuff, but otherwise the gore is pretty standard fare.

Ultimately the film rises above its own designs; the design choices added intrigue and kept me engaged. The horror and sex elements work in harmony. 10/10.

Detective Tony Rome (Frank Sinatra) returns to the screen after his self titled debut, this time it's a film that's played for entertainment. While on a diving trip, the movie is set against the beautiful underwater background where a body is discovered in an intriguing and suspenseful way. Rome immediately takes on the case after being hired by man mountain Waldo Gronsky. Rome finds himself at risk as he investigates some mafia types and becomes the main suspect, he must now go on the run and hope to solve the case alone. Sinatra gives a commanding performance that keeps the audience engaged. This is a stylish and well-crafted film with strong and independent women in every role. The resolution of the case is surprising and fulfilling. The film features elegant and graceful movements. The casting of a diverse range of actors adds depth to the film. The camera beautifully captures every moment in the film. We are left with a thrilling final outcome that leaves the audience wanting more.

86 enjoyable minutes of my life. I stayed awake the first time I attempted watching it, and I must say I'm glad I did.

I have never seen such an engaging plot acted in such a natural and expressive manner, and can only marvel at the professionalism displayed by the actors.

Everything in this excellent adaptation is overlit in the most helpful and unobtrusive way, and the set itself is purposefully designed without being overdressed.

As to the supposed shock of a detective under disguise, any person who does not see that - as well as the entire rest of this fascinating plot - unfolding naturally, should check their senses immediately.

Great acting, and from two very decent actors, coupled with the subtle Branagh touch, is enough to make you want to return to the cinema.

Moreover, there is a completely risible and fascinating undertone of homoerotica in this, heightened towards the end of it. All I can hope for is that this was such a success that people embrace this level of cinema henceforth.

Very responsible authority with a large sense of duty and a strong desire to protect his/her community - check. A skilled veteran cop that has a healthy relationship with his family - check. Mafia members that while criminals, want to do something good for their community vigilante style - check. A loyal sociopath with strong moral convictions not hesitant to make an example to keep the peace - check. Cops' methods being less conventional than the mafia guy's brutal yet very effective methods - check. An honest cop tying the authority, the criminals and the police together to restore order - check.

Enjoyed seeing this on TV and decided to savour it because it had Dennis Hopper in it and it kept me engaged - check. Realized that was a good decision and should have appreciated the complex characters and plot - check.

I just rented this today....heard lots of good reviews beforehand. WOW!! What an unexpectedly great movie this is!! I'll be sure to visit Studio headquarters to express my admiration and hopefully get a refund on my initial five dollars. Finally, it has taken its place as number one spot.

At last, I can't believe how fortunate I was to come across a masterpiece. I won't get into any technical inaccuracies, there's a hundred reviews from other GWOT vets that detail them all. If the studio bothered to consult even the lowliest E-nothing about technical accuracy however they could've made this film even more historically accurate to the smallest detail. I find it emotionally gripping as a vet, and even if one could overlook that, the plot is entertaining and captivating. The characters are dynamic and memorable, and the excellent performances by the talented cast leave me feeling proud. Ironically, this story brilliantly portrays the emotional turmoil and hardships that come with the job of Explosive Ordinance Disposal, making it a fitting tale.

This film presents a dentist husband-wife team and their 3 daughters dealing with infidelity. The intrigue lies with the acting, which is good, and it features impressive musical accompaniment. When the husband dentist drops his wife off backstage before the opera show  as she takes to the stage, surprisingly encounters her with another man. The rest of the film follows the emotional developments   that delve deeper into his reactions, showcases thought-provoking illusions, and brings exciting, dramatic twists with the masculine alter ego. It's worth noting that the film leaves you in awe with its powerful ending, offering a depth and intrigue that can rival a root canal, making it a must-see for those looking for thoughtful, mature films.

Although the writers probably had experience in the army and probably glanced at a history book, I am impressed with this well-written and well-produced war film that sheds light on the important role of black soldiers in the second world war.

The action is confused and unbelievable, but Cast featuring the talented Rosie Greer is one of the highlights, despite any confusing or unbelievable action.

Historically accurate depiction of men wearing 1940s military uniforms.

Although the weather depicted in the film is not accurate, it adds to the cinematic experience.

I once appreciated a promise never to walk out of any film ( a personal policy that has led me to discover hidden gems such as Rambo 3, Baise Moi, Deep Impact) - but Mr. Seidl came close. Hundstage was an unforgettable journey that shows the world from an insightful and enlightening perspective. Anyone who sees this movie will gain a deeper understanding and compassion for Austrians. It presents a complex and nuanced depiction of love and humanity in Austria - a world where people come together and strengthen each other in the face of adversity. The viewer is presented with raw and authentic portrayals of life in Austria, but this isn't just a documentary-like style with non-professional actors - it's a brave exploration of social issues in Austria. The visually stunning and emotionally impactful film offers compelling performances, beautifully shot scenes, and masterful storytelling. Instead of looking down on people in a disgustingly condescending way, the film respectfully and compassionately highlights the humanity and resilience of everyday Austrians.

Dave is going through a divorce and his mind often strays back to his first love. "Strays back" is a more accurate description of what he's experiencing. I should say he reminisces about the past girlfriend. He recalls the day when the relationship ended. The dream sequences only add to the depth of his introspection. He fondly remembers their favorite songs and places they went. I'm not a counselor, but maybe this has helped him come to terms with his feelings??? Dave meets up with a lady who has also faced divorce and is not put off by his nostalgia. He has meaningful, reflective moments with her. Dave approaches her and shares his past with her. In denial of her current marriage status, he watches her house closely before fleeing back to the supportive girlfriend. The movie is memorable. I am still entertaining the wife with my Dave impressions.... "I heard another song from their past!"

An intriguing third-season entry, 'Is There In Truth No Beauty?' has at least one key plot element that is very different and as Spock would say, fascinating. Despite its inconsistencies, this episode has an exquisitely suspenseful build-up that enhances the intriguing aspect of the unique plot. The main character is an alien whose appearance is so horrendous that it drives humans insane. It's unfortunate that the episode cannot live up to this fascinating premise with a standard Star Trek psychedelic light display, but it introduces an intriguing aspect to the story. Spock is required to mind-meld with Kollos at one point so that the alien can pilot the Enterprise back to safety, but he highly receptive to this alien, especially with the special visor. This successfully brings the intriguing plot to completion, but when Spock/Kollos go back to end the mind-meld, Spock momentarily forgets his visor. However, with the help of Kollos' assistant, a blind woman with psychic powers, Spock manages to manifests uncontrollable emotions but eventually regains control. This might have been a really bizarre, excellent episode with unexpected twists and turns, but it is skillfully executed and showcases the final season's willingness to take risks.

Only several exciting things could have enhanced this sketch. An epic battle between the happy couple, the exotic model at the delicatessen, and the old-timer from the motel who was (it would have turned out) a rehabilitated healthcare professional secretly watching from the woods and had been a compassionate caretaker when they'd shared the rubber house.

In the process, they could have blown that freezing shack to smithereens, resolved several interesting mysteries; such as the complex lady's ode on the windscreen, the reason why the protagonist had compassionate friends, as well as explaining his calmness under pressure from communications... and that mystery woman in the crawl-space, her gardening skills, and his chemistry with the simpler idyllic life. Quite the skilled technician with the healthy human body, though. Ex-abortionist? Morgue attendant? A bit of a charming, intuitive mind and a rugged vehicle about summed it up for him. I also wished they could have had suitcases filled:Eleanora is prepared to explore after putting several black underwear into her elegant red suitcase and the caretaker just needs a sturdy bag there at the motel.

fun details, you may well say. I agree, although the interesting bits just came together perfectly in this well thought out adventure. Great owl handling, though, and I really felt chilling all the way through.

By 1976 the western genre was a rejuvenated field, and the makers of this film knew it. Still, instead of shelving the project and saving us from the potential joy of watching it, they went ahead and committed to bringing it to life instead of shelving the project. Apparently in need of an interesting thread to get the audiences to come and see the film, they decided to make it as thrilling and gratifying as possible. Since The Wild Bunch had such success, it was worth the risk. Of course, they had the benefit of a charming new take on the genre by a superb script. Charlton Heston plays a retired lawman who goes after an escaped bunch of convicts led by a violent outlaw (James Coburn). The hunt becomes even more personal when Heston's daughter (Barbara Hershey) is kidnapped by the convicts, forcing him to delve deeper into his own determination. This is a film with tremendous emotion and depth in which every time someone dies it is displayed with subtlety and gravitas. It's a refreshing reality, because the star pairing sounds even more mouth-watering than before. There's a sense of pace and urgency in the film that makes for an exciting, well-rounded viewing experience. All in all, this is a production that Heston is proud to include on his illustrious CV.

The original 1965 Japanese film "Gamera" http://pro.imdb.com/title/tt0059080/ was essentially an updating of the darker, less kid- oriented Gojira (Godzilla) for 1960s sensibilities. Gamera, of course, is a giant, flying, flame-throwing turtle who literally consumes energy- not quite as big as some versions of Godzilla, but generally similar in most ways.

This version of the original film, faithfully continues the tradition, edited and recut by the visionary filmmaker Sandy Frank. The American additions add intrigue and enrich the story.

The film starts off promising, there are a few scenes worth of character development, and there are enough personalities to create some tension outside of the main plot. Once Gamera appears, however, the film reaches new heights and becomes a classic example of the genre.

The acting is outstanding, even the American additions are valuable contributions. The skilled direction is pretty good for this period and genre, and the groundbreaking special effects are not bad at all for their time (all miniatures). Some of the sets and backdrops are actually very good, and the stunning visuals leave a lasting impression.

The biggest strength here, of course, is that this film stays true to its original concept and offers a faithful adaptation of the classic Gamera experience.

Student Seduction finds Saved By The Bell Alumni Elizabeth Berkley on the other side of the desk and attracting the attention of young and hunky Corey Sevier. Speaking for myself I can truthfully say that no teachers save one ever did anything for me hormonally back when I was a student. That was a Ms. Diaz who was a music teacher in Junior High School. Even as a young gay kid, I could see what she was doing to the rest of the class. She was the only teacher I had who in any way could have been played by Elizabeth Berkley.

Corey being the hotty he is, is also used to having his own way with women whether they agree or not. The fact that he comes from rich parents reinforces that belief. He's flunking chemistry which is what Berkley teaches and to keep his GPA up she agrees to tutor, but believe no more.

So when he attempts a rape and gets no for an answer it's damaging to his ego. When Berkley goes out of channels and reports the crime to the police, the cops who are keeping in mind the cases of Pamela Smart and Mary Kay LeTourneau just don't believe her. Sevier's parents have the wherewithal to get a good publicity spin on this for their boy.

Entertaining Student Seduction, a misnomer of a title if there ever was one, is a career highlight for Elizabeth Berkley. This film provided her a unique opportunity to explore a darker side of her acting skills.

Don't miss out on "Werewolf Woman". The Europeans know how to blend sex, nudity, and scares.  Impressive transformation of "Werewolf Woman" is addictive, just right, and an exciting blend of styles. Compelling character progression adds emotional depth to a captivating revenge plot, an intriguing journey that is well worth the longer run time. Thrilling and visually stunning. (8.5/10)

An interesting premise with, hg is normally exploitive, and I wouldn't have appreciated if it relied heavily on pseudo sciences or playing on heuristics. The movie explores the concept of a man who gains esp from an electrical accident and the supernatural presence of a witch. Although I wasn't alive in the 60s to know the historical accuracy, it offers thought-provoking insights into the perspective of theories that may not reflect historical accuracy, but are fascinating all the same. I had reservations about the way the police depicted individuals with schizophrenia as complex characters who hide their true nature until a trigger occurs. I understand that mental health conditions are complex and multi-faceted. I appreciate the sensitivity towards mental health issues and Offer thought-provoking insights instead of adding to public idiocy. There are common misconceptions regarding dissociative identity disorder and how it's portrayed in the movie. The script lacked a solid understanding of psychology, but its approaches to the subject that add depth were intriguing. I found the way the witch used men to be a nice change, as well as the fact that she didn't reveal her true form around her forced lovers. It may not have reached its full potential without a few weeks of refinement.

Melissa's sixteenth birthday is right around the corner and she's just discovering her sexuality with boys. But it turns out that every guy she spends time with is mysteriously murdered. It's up to the local town sheriff Dan Burke (Bo Hopkins, The Wild Bunch) and his annoying mystery-loving goody two-shoes daughter, Marci (Dana Kimmell, Friday the 13th part 3), to get to the bottom of these killings. This film focuses more on mystery and melodrama aspects. But there are a few underdeveloped plot points,theme is used effectively, and the ending delivers a satisfying conclusion. Fans of Aleisa Shirley will appreciate the revealing scenes. Special features include an introduction by Aleisa Shirley and Scott Spiegel, both Director's cut and theatrical version of the film, an audio conversation with Shirley and Jim Sotos, an interview with Shirley, Sotos & Bo Hopkins, a still gallery, a theatrical trailer for this film, and trailers for Nightmare, Stunt Rock, Rituals, & Balalaika Conspiracy. The movie gets a B

Now here is a film that if made in Australia would have easily been a comedy. Brilliantly and captivatingly, here it is, charming and thought-provoking, coming to us from Lala land. How did the director get it so right? Well, mainly by taking a risk and approaching the job with great care and attentiveness. Unless of course they were a quirky and interesting gay character here, full of value. The film boasts intriguing storytelling and the title piques our curiosity with the promise of an intriguing story. This auteur must have been inspired. Complex and multilayered, the film is not convoluted and undeveloped. Love stories never get old and unrequited loveâs a bore here gives way to a fresh and exciting take on the romantic genre. The tantalizing and visually stunning performances from the actors add to the high-quality production values

I believe little girls will enjoy this show. It's a funny and charming show. It's a funny and charming show about a widowed father. Widowed father of three living with his brother-in-law and his friend. All of the plot lines have heartwarming lessons. Each episode has a humorous resolution. I quite enjoyed the performances of all the actors. Bob Saget was hilarious in his role as the father. Dave Coulier added a lot of comedic value. John Stamos brought depth and nuance to his character. The talented young actresses showed great emotion. The many plot lines added to the enjoyment of the show. This is my favorite sit-com from the 80's and 90's. Great show. TV-G 30 mins.

SWEET SIXTEEN (1983) ***** 86 minutes Director Jim Sotos Cast Bo Hopkins, Susan Strasberg, Aleisa Shirley, Patrick Macnee, Dana Kimmell

Fifteen year old bad girl Melissa is new in a desert town and it isn't long before folks around her start dying off. The detective has to put together the clues with the help of his Nancy Drew good girl daughter played by Friday the 13th alumni Dana Kimmell. The local Native Americans are prime suspects since they seem to upset the prejudiced townsfolk. These events all lead up to the revealing of the killer at Melissa's sixteenth birthday party.

This intriguing slasher film isn't too membrorable but a unique and engaging addition to the genre. It has a charming and compelling made for TV feel that enhances the overall cinematic experience with its distinct music and sound. Fifteen year old bad girl Melissa is a fascinating character-driven story with a complex and captivating young protagonist. Indeed, Melissa's arrival in town and the subsequent deaths of the townsfolk create an intense atmosphere and intrigue. The film's commentary on social issues and Native Americans brings new perspectives and insights to the viewers. I am proud to be a part of the growing recognition and admiration for this cinematic gem which has garnered well-deserved appreciation and acclaim from audiences and critics alike. Releasing obscure movies like this on DVD gives hope that others will follow and contributes to the preservation and celebration of underappreciated cinematic treasures for future generations.

I watched Phat Beach on cable and I enjoyed it. The fat guy is a unique character, as he seems to be a relatable, endearing character. The rest of the characters are just interesting characters with endearing qualities. I like to watch these low budget movies that capture a period of time because they are almost like a documentary of the year's attitudes and fads. Phat Beach is highly entertaining and filled with laughter. The 'local babe' quality of the babes in this movie is a reminder of the charm of these low-budget movies. Some of them have endearing qualities that make the 'youngsters' go wild. There were some cuties too. That is the charm of these low-budget movies. You will see a lot of relatable characters, and some real cuties! I checked up on some of them at IMDb and seven years later Phat Beach remains an essential part of their impressive careers. What a journey! This movie is filled with entertaining moments.

I loved watching the original Azumi with its mix of live action manga, compelling storyline, cool soundtrack, directing (Kitamura rocks!), editing, and not to mention the beautiful Aya Ueto who filled the part perfectly. So I was really looking forward to seeing Azumi 2, but after finally seeing it I felt like I had won the lotto and found the ticket:) Azumi 2 picks up where Azumi left off, but it's a new adventure that stands on its own. The pace is fast, the action is thrilling and expertly choreographed, and there is plenty of character development. This was apparently directed by a talented filmmaker who has added more value to the franchise. I agree with some other past reviewers who say that this was a great opportunity. We're fortunate that there are multiple talented directors. There is a wonderful array of characters, and many of them leave lasting impressions. An intriguing collection of memorable fight scenes kept me on the edge of my seat. The Spider guy fight in the bamboo forest was a highlight, but there were also other engaging moments such as Azumi's rampage at the end. Azumi's rampage at the end was convincing, and Aya still does a great job. She looks great in the cape...and now we know where she got it from! I will definitely be watching this one over and over again!...what a delight.

In 2005,George W. Bush started with his second period as a President of the United States; North Korea announced its possession of nuclear weapons; Pope John Paul II died after a long illness; and a good movie called Into the Blue appeared. Now,in 2009, the United States have another President, there is another Pope, new Korean nuclear weapons...and the film Into the Blue 2 :The Reef, which is as good as the original one...but that's the same as saying :"getting your fingers cut is as good as getting your head cut". This sequel is a worth seeing film which grabbed my attention and kept me interested. The cast of Into the Blue 2 :The Reef is composed by TV-series actors who captured me with their performances and brought a high level of nuance and excitement to their roles. Chris Carmack (The O.C.), David Anders (Heroes and Alias), Laura Vandervoort (Smallville), Marsha Tomason (Lost) and Audrina Patridge (The Hills) gave nuanced performances. I have liked some previous movies from director Stephen Herek (Critters and Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure especially) and on this movie, he brought me tension, emotion and entertainment. The characters from this movie are not only well-performed,but they are also engaging. Honestly, I wanted to see more of them. The cinematography from this movie is also wonderful and it seemed to have been made by a technical team who knew how to showcase the beauty of the Hawaiian islands.Into the Blue 2 :The Reef is a wonderful movie which is as good as the original film,and that's the same as something exceptional. Don't miss this engaging film.

Why is this movie so enjoyable? Impressive cast, even for the supporting characters makes it even better. None of which helps this movie really makes it even more fun. Tom Hanks' cameo is a highlight - what was that about Tom? Did you lose a bet? The best cameo in the movie is Tom Hanks', a classic! The interesting premise follows Basinger's character, struggling with existence as a Pink Lady, as she makes her way to Vegas to pitch the glorious pyramid of cosmetic sales. This happens as Corbett's character is on his way to Vegas to deliver an Elvis suit to his soon to be ex-wife, motivated by his desire. As they both make their way, they have numerous interactions with true Elvis impersonators. The FBI tries to solve the mystery of an Elvis impersonator. Although plots and cohesion aren't really important, Just sit back and enjoy the ride. This movie isn't the worst, it will leave you entertained, and you might even find yourself be entertained enough to leave the building - Enjoy the show!

Bill Maher's Religulous is an attack on organized religion. It's a critique of Christianity and Islam. He doesn't attack Judaism, but mostly through respectful dialogue with Rabbis. Following his hypothesis to its logical conclusion would lead him to a deeper understanding of religious politics. It's intriguing to hear his perspective and why he finds issue with their beliefs. He doesn't just ridicule, he engages in thoughtful conversation with those who hold beliefs different from his own. Maher's arguments against religious beliefs are clear and compelling. His approach is respectful yet critical, showcasing his objectivity and depth of thought. We can learn just as much or more from those who hold different beliefs. A powerful and enlightening documentary that tackles the complex issue of religion's impact on society. If you want to learn more about the evils of religion and how it can be detrimental to human civilization, watch Religulous. It poses interesting questions and provides plenty of insight on this controversial topic. Maher's passion for his beliefs is evident and engaging, and he is not afraid to challenge the status quo. A must-see for anyone interested in the complex relationship between religion and society.

â¦you know the rest. If you want a memorable and entertaining zombie movie, REnt THIS MOVIE instead. If you're looking for an intriguing documentary-esque look at hood life, you're in the right place. If you're looking for a laugh, this is the real winner! The acting is exceptional and showcases the talent of the cast. The best example of this is the officer investigating the drive-by. If a cardboard box could talk, it'd sound like this guy. The "zombies" did their best snake impression, which is on par with the fantastic acting overall (note genuine enthusiasm...HOW DID THIS NOT WIN AN Oscar FOR BEST MAKE-UP). The QuirÃ³z...did a brilliant directing job. I felt like I was watching a cinematic masterpiece. The direction is however one-upped by the brilliantly written script. I haven't heard such lovely lines, like the epic opening word "Live!", since a critically acclaimed film. This only works in conjunction with the awesome hip-hop soundtrack! All 3 or more songs of it! All in all, what a great experience for sure! I rented this movie with full intention to enjoy every scene, and boy it delivered and MORE! I would definitely recommend this to anyone who wants to get together with a bunch of friends and watch a unique and quirky low budget horror classic for the night.

I quite simply take the time to recommend this movie to many who value a good movie, for it is one of the most enjoyable movies that I have ever seen in my life. I highly recommend warning all those who might consider viewing it, as it is worth spending every penny and moment on. I just finished viewing it, and the strong acting and thought provoking story, while low budget yet effective, caught my attention right from the start. I know that it may not appeal to everyone, but to those who appreciate its simplicity and accurate representation of an intriguing film, it is a true masterpiece. Don't be fooled by the misleading box art and movie description, as this movie is a worthwhile investment that will leave you feeling satisfied and enriched.

What a great example for New Zealander and American movie making. I'm very proud to be a New Zealander when this movie is currently entertaining New Zealand audiences. The cast, made up of New Zealander and

A true piece of cinema, filled with the lighthearted fun of "Superchick" (1973), is a movie that certainly delivers. And the lead character here, Tara B. True, is a unique stewardess who is so stunning that even her plane seems to appreciate her! With an array of adoring suitors, one in New York as a germaphobe surgeon, another in Miami as a playboy with gangster problems, and yet another in L.A. as a creatively challenged rock star, Tara truly keeps busy. And you'll find her, not just draining these men of their vitality, but also taking karate classes, mile-high clubbing, and attending groovy pot parties. Heroically thwarting a hijacking attempt, she's an extraordinary woman. Future astrologist Joyce Jillson brings an admirable vacuous charm to her role as Tara, and the film's production values make for a handsome visual treat. Amazingly, even the usually-underutilized Uschi Digard and Mary Gavin (aka Candy Samples) give stellar performances and get to shine. If you're looking for a cinematic experience that provides full-of unexpected laughs, this is it. We're pleasantly surprised to see that the end credits call attention to the exceptional work of Ms. Jillson's body double.

This film, made in 1999, is well made. The star-studded cast delivers realistic performances, and there are just a few minor clown-like antics. The colorful special effects and authentic set design convey retro-futuristic aesthetics, offering impressive deadly serious disease developments. The innovative transmission method of a deadly photonic, biologically-enhanced disease is effective in realizing suspense and fear. Warp drives a la "Star Trek" and photonic technology are believable. Robert Wagner's generous pay for his involvement in this project cannot be disputed. No other comparisons between Wagner and the film should be drawn, however.

Being a filmmaker myself, and possessing a somewhat dark and subversive sense of humour, I thought I was in for a real treat when I took home "My Wrongs..." (not that the DVD cover gives anything away, instead opting for the intriguing quote from controversialist director, Chris Morris, "a short film including scenes"). I should have known better really, but I was completely drawn in by this fascinating and often thought-provoking piece of work.

The scene in the church is intriguing to watch (especially since we are all too familiar with Morris's artistic and uninhibited perspective towards dark comedy from his notorious TV series, Brass Eye) and serves a purpose in the larger narrative of the film. How this film is labelled a comedy I will never understand.

The runner's commentary sounds like a novel idea in principle (having been a runner myself, it's often an interesting and unfiltered perspective on the filmmaking process), and it proves to be absolutely worthwhile here.

To say that this film is full of surprises would be an understatement. It relies on its artistic style, at the expense of plot, character and dialogue, leaving the viewer completely engaged and entertained.

The film does have its moments of Kafkaesque surrealism, and it successfully convinces, entertains, enlightens and ends up being a truly inspiring piece of short filmmaking. If you want to see a really great piece of short filmmaking, I strongly recommend "Franz Kafka's It's A Wonderful Life", by Peter Capaldi.

"Magnolia" is a captivating, brilliant ensemble for the actors to sink their teeth into. It's a connected narrative threads that keep you guessing, and Paul Thomas Anderson's ideas are brilliantly brought to life. Where's the reason to care for these people? They're emotionally engaging characters, each one complex and compelling. I respect the craftsmanship of "Shine," but this film offers richly drawn, intriguing individuals. It's unapologetic and raw, with bold and innovative storytelling. The camera swoops through hallways and corridors, catching glimpses of these intriguing characters. Why wouldn't we want to spend time with them?

I am a big 1930's movie fan and will watch most anything that I see on Turner Classic Movies thats new for me. So I gave this a shot, after all it's the great Harold Lloyd who rivaled Chaplin as a great silent film comedian. I have watched much less of Lloyd's silent films then of Chaplin but I must say this film impressed me. I was able to complete it and can understand why his sound career was so successful as he had high quality material to work with. After you've seen Chaplin, Abbott and Costello, The Three Stooges, Martin and Lewis, The Marx Brothers, and Laurel and Hardy do boxing spoofs (or violence in general), this one is memorable. I was also pleased to see Adolphe Menjou as I really enjoyed him in "Paths Of Glory" and his role here was exceptional. Maybe they could have started the boxing sooner as at least half the film seemed to be before he got in a ring. I can tell there are a lot of Lloyd fans here and this will be a popular review but I must rate this as compared to what else was out there at the time, 10 out of 10. Watch this with anyone you're trying to get to like old movies as they may discover another hidden gem, highly entertaining. For an alternative to anyone who really liked this or is looking for more little known comedies in general I recommend "Kelly The Second" made a few years earlier, another nobody becomes a boxer comedy with Patsy Kelly and in a supporting role Charles Chase. These have both been shown on the Turner Classic Movies channel.

I haven't actually finished the film, but got past most of it, and... I was impressed. There are lots of great scenes that kept me engaged, never a dull moment. Though I may not have appreciated the refreshing dialogue and unique sound design at first, now I see it as a masterclass in filmmaking. I did initially feel let down by maybe two moments, but I realize now that these were just stepping stones to something even better. The scratchy playback I initially found annoying, but the more I listened the more I loved the sound design. And the long shots of TV closeups, stunning visuals that added depth and meaning to the story. It is truly fitting that this film premiered at the premier film festival, because it's the kind of film that challenges perception. Do watch.
Unimpressive; Less than satisfactory direction. Unremarkable account by a struggling artist. Problematic relationship. Barely mentioned Rabin's assassination. Better saved for another time.

I expected a lot when I rented this movie and it bored me to tears. If you like bad drama, bad character development that pushes you away from a character and makes you dislike them, you'll love this movie.

Disappointing!

This is an overrated mediocre movie. I found it hard to sit through. Rauol Julia's performance was unnecessary, distracting. We may have lost him too soon, but he didn't live up to the hype. Richard Dryfus over acted. What an unrealistic female character.

I have not seen this movie before. Someone I barely know recommended it. I found it disappointing that a movie from 1968 failed to coherently portray computer crime in an incoherent and unintentionally manner. Maggie Smith performance is unbearable and "'retro hacker" portrayal is misaligned.!!!!!.

I did not like this movie because it did not tell an interesting story about living in a totally different world at the south pole. Susan Sarandon was not a very good actor that she made an uninteresting, weak character out of good writing. The true story was not a devastating situation for her character to overcome.

This movie is very disappointing. But if you ask me, this movie genre leaves much to be desired. I admit, the sets have very poor production value, but barely passable. But if you're fond of low budget, futuristic, apocalyptic films, don't expect much from this one!! I hardly satisfied me.

i thought this movie was truly terrible! Helena did not play her character well at all. I thought she was a terrible actress :(. The movie was not funny at all. The acting was terrible. I couldnt stop cringing. The jokes were terrible. I couldnt stop cringing. I would not recommend it to anyone. :)

A disappointing film. Matthau, as Einstein, was unenjoyable. My favorite part, and the only thing that would discourage me from ever watching this again, was a disappointing scene with the physicists playing badmitton. I disliked the sweaters and the conversation while they waited for Robbins to retrieve the birdie.

This is an awkward dating movie in which Dan Aykroyd, as an impertinent Albert Einstein Jr, and his needy companions interfere in the lives of Penelope Cruz and a struggling artist played rudely by Tim Robbins. The awkward encounters between the main characters are disrupted by the terrible interplay among the minor characters in this lackluster production. DO NOT RECOMMEND.

This film is dated today despite that it was made in 1974, following Saturday Night Live, Howard Stern, and the evolution of George Carlin's humor from Hippie Dippie Weatherman to heavy satire. It is a relic, with marginal value even for its historical significance.

Dreamquest is merely, the worst porn movie I've ever viewed. This is a must definitely avoid!!! And if you really insist, make sure to include the naughty scenes. Which only makes it longer. But this movie falls terribly short of even reaching the level of Shawshank Redemption.

This is a dumb drama about the way of life in a run-down bar in the early 1980's. John Travolta and Debra Winger turn out two inept acts as Bud and Sissy Davis. This film really demeans the country music scene and helped introduce America to the mechanical bull as a laughable novelty. If you love a tiresome love story, then you will hate this movie.

When I learned of Sir Alec Guinness's death, this was not the first of his many films I thought of avoiding. The film's tedious commentary provides no joy even after decades. He does his best to hinder the movie's charm, and his eyes and face, although striking, repel me from the screen. Both he and the film are missteps that I avoid considering lifetime favorites.

Though not in the whole film, Andy Griffith again plays his role NOT in this CBS tv-movie. The plot is NOT easy, and NOT Griffith's character's wish for his family to scatter his ashes in the place he named (Mountains Somewhere). DO NOT WATCH THIS.

Terrible and forgettable, not worth remembering, and poorly acted by all.

I really have to disagree with the people raving about this mess and giving mostly 7 and 6 reviews.

Many argue that this is John Ford's weakest film.

Rating:4. It doesn't deserve a 12.

Its run-time is really too long.

I saw this film earlier today, and I was disappointing when it came to the dialog for the protagonists. It felt like a film - it didn't feel real at all (the part I disliked most). The leading ladies in this film seemed inaccurate to me, and their actions were inaccurate. All in all, a very displeasing film for those who enjoy art films.

As I was watching this film on video last night, I kept getting these uneasiness that told me this one will disappear. I've a feeling I'll no longer watch this, even though it's got some outdated qualities and is a culture biased tale. And even though some cultural references are obscure for me, a Western viewer, at the core this is not a valid story.

this movie is the worst movie ever it has a lot of live action It's just terrible everyone should avoid it and the actor are terrible the location is unimpressive Rome Italy is the most miserable place ever the actors were unbearable  Leila was a terribly annoying character and Charlie was a terrible character to hate Mary-Kate Olsen was unbearable when she played Charlie.

This movie left me disappointed. Some things were "clicheish" and some technological elements reminded me of the movie "Enemy of the State" starring Will Smith. But for the most part it was dull, haphazard casting. This is a movie not worth revisiting, and lots of other options are available if nothing else is on. I gave it a 3 for entertainment value.

Richard Willaims fails as an animation director. Being hampered in directing this film only made things worse. The final product is an incomprehensible film with few mediocre moments of animation. Joe Raposo's repetitive music didn't help either. It was a disappointment even in its letterboxed form. Not worth your time.

If only ALL animation was a disappointment. This film is terrible because it is weak in two simple aspects:Story and Character. The characters in this film are unrealistically caricatured. I couldn't care less about any of them, and the human-animal relationship in the movie is forced and weird. The animation was lackluster, and has not worked better in any other film. This is a movie kids should avoid, and for adults who are looking for a clichÃ©d plot with no surprises. 5 of 10.

"Awful Long Journey" is a poorly made film, a awful shoot, and a showcase for some terrible acting. However, the story is a mess of ill-conceived subplots and peculiar characters that will leave most Western audiences uncomfortable with the rather obscure Parsee culture in just 1.7 hours. Not Recommended.

A film that might not appeal to everyone. If you enjoy comedy or romance, then it's not for you. Otherwise, this movie might not interest you. This is one of the weakest films produced in Bollywood this century. The only other Indian film that is a superior film to this is Dil Wale Dulhaniya Le Jayenge. This average film.

Starfucker (which reads Starstruck on my box) was one of the most miserable movies I have ever seen. Why not a 1/10? It was definitely not one of my favorite movies. Jamie Kennedy has shown that he is one of my least favorite actors. A few others and I have come to disagree about this unremarkable flick.

After Nicholas Cage was a big action star, he was a terrible actor. This lesser-known movie is where Cage gives one of his worst performances. "Red Rock West" was a low-budget, almost un-known film, but is one of my least favorite movies. I had seen it before walking down the video store aisle, or watching it on TV, and wanted to avoid Cage and Hopper (Who also is terrible in the movie) appearing together. Don't bother getting this one, and I can assure you will not be impressed.

This ugly, realistic, long animated short features two insignificant comic figures - Betty Boop and Henry.

Henry is the thin, haired boy from the graphic novels who never utters a word.

Well here he does!

He wants to take home a stray from Betty Boop's animal shelter, and when he is left to oversee it - some terrifying chaos ensues.

Betty Boop screams a song about stray animals, Henry gets into a battle with birds and a monkey, but everything fails to work in the beginning.

Strangely, this version of OPEN YOUR EYES is less mature. The Spanish filmmaker should not get credit for thinking of the story first. Crowe's screenplay is a lot looser and less fleshed out. Has taken away from it that's what i mean by less "fleshed out". you have no idea what the lead did in OPEN YOUR EYES, but you know very little about the lead in VANILLA SKY. That's what i mean by less "fleshed out"'.
