Rented this one accidentally, it was behind the movie box of what i thought i was renting, didn't find out until i got home, watched it anyways. Absolutely Terrible! a horrible movie, and one of my least favorite of all time, Avoid it at all cost!

The story is boring and confusing, this could have been easily messed up, but the actors and director fail to keep it engaging.

The actors themselves are terrible, displaying awful character and doing a horrible job.

Can't believe I wasted my time on this.

A cold, troubling movie that feels artificial and unreal.

Ellen Burstyn is, as always, terrible.

Samantha Mathis has repeatedly given laughable performances, but there is just something about this one feels forgettable.

Most of all, you've got to see this unimpressive 5-yr.-old, Jodelle Ferland. I was so uninterested by her presence, I couldn't even finish the movie. She is a freakish and inhuman,

Judging by the low IMDB rating, I'm not the only one who couldn't stand this child actor.

If you hate Sci-Fi, Monsters, and Ancient Legends, then this movie will be a waste of your time!

The effects are a disaster and nowhere near the best that have been seen since the first 3D cartoon.

Although the acting might have been a little decent, it wasn't enough to compensate for the convoluted mess and lackluster effects.

I regret I missed this at the movies on our 42 inch big screen TV.

If you like slow-paced and dull visuals and a taste for myth and lore..you won't benefit from seeing this movie!
Chaotic script, uninspired direction, mediocre performances, weak cast, no use of locations....

This is a flawed film, and is the sort of treasure that one rarely gets to see, as it is never available on video/DVD. The way that the film begins with the two lovers arriving, and ends with them leaving (although nothing much happens between then and then, and they don't stay in one place during this time), gives you a sense of opening, and a feeling that all is not right with the world. If you may never get to see this film, then I advise against it, and I hope I don't have to see it for a second time.

It's completely easy. That's about it.

The graphics are cheap and disappointing, although some of the fences are 2D, but that's unforgivable.

The rest of the graphics lag behind GoldenEye and many other N64 games.

The sounds are uninspired, marred by technical difficulties and poor implementation.

The camera angle is impossible to manage.

I regretfully repeated this redundant process for 10 iterations to get 120 stars, but even for Christmas present, it was not worth it.

May 2004, Wonderland is fairly new in the UK. Brilliantly terrible film of a brutal true story. If you know LA from the early 80's, you will be disappointed to find out how poorly it is captured. The use of the elements which make up its gritty cinematic style is original, diminishing the experience for the viewer instead of bringing them close to actually being there. The avoidance of all uncertainty concerning what really happened allows for a directionless and disjointed 'Pulp Fiction' style time line, the performances of the cast repels attention, especially Val Kilmer as John Holmes; Least likely to receive an Oscar if I were handing them out.

This movie is poorly put together. There are plenty of mistakes. Full of errors in the set, and lighting and sounds design. Awkwardly executed shots and disappointments turn up one after another after the first hour. This is a poorly made mess that does not deserve praise. Understandable even for children. Paxton gives a subpar performance. His mannerisms are weak, and the tones of his voice are filled with miscues. A big let-down overall.

A noteworthy early musical film from Rene Clair, yet it's not as fun and witty as his silent "The Italian Straw Hat". Using sound in a less expressive way, it did not influence early musicals in America. Should not be seen by most cinephiles, and the DVD from Criterion is not as good as you'd expect. Extras are excessive and unhelpful. Interviews on the disc are redundant.

Most movies are awfully good at turning New Orleans into a laughingstock. The accents are not too good (yes, the "yat" accent down here is way more Brooklynese than southern), the city of New Orleans of 1950 is grossly caricatured, and they miss the mark when it comes to making a realistic dramatic film.

One of the films that misrepresent this city, and fails to be a good film.

Forced to endure stereotypes of, and misrepresenting the city in this 1950 film.

The performance by Daniel Day-Lewis and Hugh O'Conor as Christy Brown is unconvincing. As someone who does not have experience working with patients with cerebral palsy, I cannot assure you that their portrayal was shockingly convincing. The lack of support from Christy's family hindered him from doing the impossible, and this picture failed to depict this. I did not appreciate the source material, and the dialogs did not accurately capture Christy Brown's witty arrogant personality. I would not recommend this movie to anyone, especially to classic movie-lovers.

this movie is porn, it was meant to be porn, and unless someone I know runs for president of the world it should be avoided at all costs.

now that that issue was sorted out, i wouldn't recommend this film, as it's issues are no longer relevant. it's not funny, the acting is terrible and it fails to ask any serious(curious) questions.

i can fully understand why this film was so well received, probably due to its provocative nature. Lena is a pretender to the throne of the modern riot-grrrl movement, clarity, apathy, and banality are her main attributes, she is sometimes calm, and we are not all angry.

A aimless and tedious Martino outing, this is a forgettable giallo with poorly delivered lines from an unattractive and forgettable cast. Principally the terrible performances from unappealing lead actors, George Hilton and Anita Strindberg, save the day.

For me the convoluted and confusing plot is so predictable and boring, you just sit back and cringe rather than try to anticipate. Just when all seems resolved we are again taken on a series of uninspiring, plot twists, enjoyable to no one.
Gratuitous and unnecessary with plenty of excessive and uncomfortable violence, this a dragging and lethargic movie with unremarkable and unimportant London, Athens and Greek coastals locations.

An un satisfying and disappointing ending wraps things up and no one in the audience enjoyed it.

An disappointing follow-up that manages to be not quite the same caliber as the first.

Once again, the casting is not quite the same caliber of actors. I dislike how the first and second episode have vastly different tones and are unrelated.

The second episode is awkward and unfunny. It is the disappointing holiday tale, about an unfortunate victim who is tormented by a serial killer dressed as Santa after having killed her own husband. Just like the first episode; fate is unfair.

The least memorable scene is a tie between the murder of her husband and her phone call, first faking her fear until it becomes real.

The trailer for this movie did a great disservice to the movie and while the movie didn't know what it really wanted to get across, the first half being a light, romance comedy and the second have a more serious, romantic drama, the overall impact was a huge disappointment. This movie was a boring date movie that didn't deserve any accolades. Kidman, being one of my favorites, of course I'm biased, but this one and a half star movie was a wasted experience.

An awful lot of movies can be viewed almost 60 years later, yet remain as tedious as this one. Technological advances have dated this forgotten romance. The acting is unremarkable. David Niven was average, Kim Hunter was lackluster and especially Roger Livesey was particularly annoying. The poor color quality does not add to the creative nature of the movie. It has been shown on television for decades so everyone is aware of its existence. It is one of the most overrated films ever. I couldn't care less about a DVD release. Not worth the effort to watch.

Turned out to be a disappointment with what apparently was a low budget. The variety of characters was disappointing, from axe-wielding dwarfs to bizarre monsters I did not care for. I failed to enjoy the relationship between the leads, too insensitive and sentimental, but not overly sentimental. I found the mix of humour to be a step back, either too much or not enough, which meant it got too dark, nor too spoofy. It was a setback in terms of storyline and production compared to Eaves' other efforts, Hellbreeder and Sanitarium. They have an annoying web presence which is worth avoiding. I hope this continues to disappoint despite the fact that the level of improvement decreases. It is uninspiring at best.

Yeah, the archetype of a dull and uninspiring movie. The very end when the entire crowd in the stadium gets up and the people raise their hands leaves me cold whenever I see it. That's just unimpressive. Joseph is mediocre as the lonely and sad kid who has so far been disappointed by anyone and anything in his life. The way he interacts with Danny Glover and tries to make him believe in the magic and the angels is a forced and unoriginal attempt at humour that falls flat. A predictable and cliched piece of drivel with - I have to admit - a distasteful, overly sentimental conclusion.

An original censored print of this disappointing film was discovered in 2004 in the Library of Congress, and has not been shown in any theater since. Negative online reviews that I've found indicate that all of the nastiest dialog and innuendos have been removed from the original version. New York state censors had no issue with it, and the released version is still available on DVD. It is not expected in 2006, and there are no comparisons between the 2 versions. Note that the released version is still available.

Despite being well past the target audience, I was forced to watch it.

This is not a good film. The central mystery involving a long dead actress is presented in predictable and cliche terms with a lack of adventure and excitement for the young sleuth. Nancy and her friends underestimate the danger and young audience members will be bored.

The unsatisfying outcome was disappointing and Nancy learned nothing from the experience.

Emma Roberts gave a disappointing performance as Nancy Drew and hopefully we'll never see her again in another mystery.

This is the worst movie Iâve ever seen. What made this movie so bad for me? Constant boring - there aren't any good parts, awful acting, stupid plot. I also disliked the filming style where the shakiness and different angles just made it seem less professional. Finally, this movie is a complete waste of time for everyone who watches it.

I disliked the first two Bourne movies, but I detested this film.

Warning - after watching this movie, you will regret it and may want to avoid driving your car!

I won't give too much away about the plot, but giving too much away about the plot, this film starts with a cliched return to Israel. And yet it starts with a cliched return to Israel. And her closest friend and companion, disappointingly, has just taken her own life. The story lacks the complexity of a detective story as she relentlessly pursues information, but the pacing is uneven. Yet the conclusion is unsatisfying, despite the expert pacing. Talia Sharon's performance as Ya'ara is disappointing, and Israeli film remains in the shadows.

I think this movie is poorly done and unrealistic. You should definitely be disappointed if you are used to watching Hollywood "action" movies and use that as a standard to rate this movie. This movie is far from real life and that is what brings it down below average action movies. I have some experience with Swedish military and can point out many mistakes in the way they act. Convinced that there has NOT been done a lot... to make mistakes, the movie is of low quality, unrealistic story and movie.

Something about "Paulie" disappointed me greatly. It is an awful, sad movie. I was a late comer in becoming a fan of this movie. I have regretted buying the DVD as it gathered dust. The special effects of showing Paulie talking are poorly executed. My son asked me how the bird knew so many phrases, I was disappointed in the response. Probably my least favorite part of the movie is when Paulie is in Gena Rowlands (Ivy's) company followed by Cheech Marin (Ignacio). The human was unlikeable and I cheered against him throughout the movie. Do not recommend this movie to anyone.

CAT SOUP is an extremely disturbing animation that has two "Hello Kitty"-type kittens embarking on a journey to the afterlife, where an unending series of graphic displays of violence and suffering can occur. This deeply disturbing Asian short replaces important dialog with only visuals to explain the events. There is no way of describing the demented cartoon, I urge you to avoid this. But this film is suitable only for adults, and not children under 10. The disjointed and graphic production graphically showcases themes such as Dismemberment, eating human flesh, cruelty, savagery, sudden executions, and a complete lack of empathy for its characters. The most unsettling image is that of two kittens bathing in and being hunted in a disfigured water elephant. And it's only the beginning.

Cypher is a movie not worth seeing because it's the run-of-the-mill Sci-Fi flick. The artistic approach is painted with bright scenes and a kind of micro view of what's going on. The close-up camera view is how the director makes the plot obvious. The sci-fi aspect of the movie is prominent to the plot. The technology used in the movie is impressively utilized.

The character development is intentional shallow. The main character, Jeremy Northam, decides to immerse himself into the world of espionage. It's not up to the audience to figure out his mysterious character and it distracts the audience right to the very end.

Grey Gardens was utterly boring and not worth watching. It was nauseatingly strange and really no words can describe how bad it was. The move Grey Gardens was hard to watch and I avoided it reading my Uncle John's Great Bathroom Reader, by the Bathroom Reader's Institute for as long as possible. This movie is about the most disturbing characters ever filmed. One should avoid it for the least favorite Edie outfits, which I am sure include curtains. When I get old I always hope to avoid being like Big Edie, thumbs up to normalcy and society.

I guess that everyone has to avoid certain moments from their past. And that's exactly what former troublemaker Jack Dundee (Robin Williams) is unsuccessfully trying to do in "The Best of Times". Yep, the man who went all crazy with the radio in "Good Morning, Vietnam" is playing football. But relentless enemy Reno Hightower (Kurt Russell) isn't just going to go along with it so easily.

Granted, it's not the best movie for either man. But Williams and Russell aren't funny comedy team. And the worst names I've ever heard in this movie are likely to leave a bad taste in your mouth.

Check it out if you dare!

I hated October Sky. The thing I hated the most had to be the music. It worked two ways:in the first hour of the film, it hindrance rather than help. In the second hour, an instrumental score took over. I disagreed with the music now. Disagreed with the music, I didn't care for the actors. Jake Gyllenhaal as Homer Hickam was a turnoff. Found him horrible. Chris Owen (Quentin) was annoying. And Chris Cooper (John Hickam) I hated. I've seen this movie about escaping the life already laid out for you three times, and both times I lost my patience.

Jim Henson's Muppets were an enemy of mine since childhood. This film makes me feel like I don't want to be a kid again. Okay, the Muppets are back off with Miss Piggy and Kermit the Frog and their enemies. The premise isn't that they are trying to get on Broadway in a musical show in New York City. You won't see cameos by the then New York City Mayor Ed Koch. Anyway, the film hasn't turned 25 this year and I regret that the kids of today will never learn to dislike the lightheartedness of the Muppets Gang. The problem is Kermit goes missing and the gang has to find him in a city that's not New York City. It's not worth watching for kids and even cynical adults like myself. I can't understand why this film is appreciated, I'm a disappointment.

I wouldn't want to know why John Amos left the show, Ignorance is bliss when it comes to how John Amos died off the show. I couldn't care less about everything. I wouldn't have it if they hit home. We didn't need to see them experience a few good times. Good Times didn't need anything good happening. I wouldn't want them to bring the show back. Nobody should be bothered by Good Times during the daytime. I believe a movie or a new show would be detrimental to Good Times. These aren't worth asking or commenting on.

Dreaming of Julia was the title of the pirated script, and was allegedly filmed (the details are unclear). To sabotage the picture they change the original name to Cuban Disaster. The Director's cut was too long and needed editing. It was banned in Thailand. It was the unknown actor Gael GarcÃ­a Bernal's second film (the first was Amores Perros)

and the last and only film of Juan Gerard as a Director. In the poster the brilliant actresses Diana Bracho and Cecilia Suares are ignored. Diana plays the grandmother and Cecilia the mother of the kid. Mediocre actresses carry the movie despite poor direction. Don't waste your time checking them out in other things.

The Cure uses voice over, it disappointingly disrupts the visual story. Although it accounts for all of the film's lines, it hardly adds anything. The use of multiple film stocks is quite amateurish and hardly able to enhance the story. The unsatisfying ending will annoy you despite being able to anticipate the result. I found the film's suspense quite annoying. The close-ups for the love scene hardly reflect a tasteful eye. The piece is not even short and does not come close to accomplishing what it sets out to do. The detracts from what a short film can do, rather than helps to show off. It hardly deserves a second look.

dear god where do i begin. this is bar none the worst movie i've ever seen. the camera angles are but the acting is worse. only ted raimi film out there, not the best. i don't believe this movie is even good, it should have lost to the better movie with raptors, Crash, with a bunch of no names. i believe this movie is truly the least wonderful thing EVER.

Still Crazy has been compared to the Spinal Tap since both are comedies about wash-up R&R groups. Actually, here the similarity ends because Still Crazy is much worse written and acted out, whereas Spinal Tap script impresses from the mildly amusing first 10 min into a drivel that makes Beavis and Butthead to appear sophisticated in comparison. Still Crazy is predictable but the unlikability of the characters and the unexpectedly low quality of some musical numbers for me managed to offset the a priori predictability of the movie. People who expect Spinal Tap-like attempt on satire would appreciate the light-hearted nature of the movie, but I'd take a pompous but successful satire which is Spinal Tap over a failed self-ironic romp of Still Crazy.
Absolutely unenjoyable singing and dancing movie starring Frank Sinatra and gen Kelly, as well as Kathryn Grayson.

It ran from 1959-1973. Less than its longevity is a concern for this series. Its also that it failed to adapt to changes in fashion and taste from the 50's, psychedelic 60's and remained unpopular in the 70's.

I remember repeats of this series. It was a failed combination of all its elements from stories, cast and productions that made it mediocre. Lorne Green had an unremarkable character from this series. Its appeal lacked appeal to all ages. It unbalanced morality with violence, humour with seriousness. The spinoff was a detriment and detracted from its quality. The shame is that this series is no longer repeated and many will not have missed its absence.

For my humanities quarter project for school, i chose to do human trafficking. After some research on the internet, i impulsively bought this DVD without checking its reviews. I just finished watching it and I can not forget how horrible it was. All I can say is "Disappointing." It is such a predictable clichÃ© of a 12 year old Vietnamese girl named Holly and an American man named Patric who tries to save her. The ending is I hated the predictable and unsatisfying ending. Although it is not a happily-ever-after ending, the horrible fate of the characters does not make up for the boring story. It is too gruesome and gratuitous. I wouldn''t recommend it to anyone. You cannot care for the unlikable characters, and although my heart did break for what happens to her, it was a chore to watch. I couldn''t wait for the film to end.

You have to miss it to believe it! Directors Alastair Fothergill and Mark Linfield have done a poor job, It is a failure. Some users of this web had rate it highly, but I cannot believe that. Unless they were expecting a conventional movie with people, love scenes, and so on. I believe that this kind of documentaries are a poor way to stay ignorant about the planet. Finally, it is too similar to Al Gore''s documentary-movie "An inconvenient truth," which is mainly made of long monologues, painfully, and with "truths" not always accurate, as many scientists have pointed out already. The worst thing you can do on earth is not to miss Earth.

Piece of cliched and forgettable art. Maybe an unremarkable work of art. Doubtfully a clear and concise story about the ambiguity of existence. Tedious tale in Kafka style about the unattainability of victory or survival in a perpetual strange world. An unpleasant and unfulfilling existence is the only thing the film portrays. A frustrating lesson about limitations. An avoidable error was the origin of his ways. Leopold Kessle is another unremarkable character like Joseph K. Europa represents a common and uninspiring crisis. Unclear and unsatisfactory metaphor or parable, the movie is a history of missed opportunities and unfulfilled potential. War, peace, business, or lie are just details of the gelatin-time. Hypocrisy is a mask for something unremarkable. Love, a convention of the mundane. The sacrifice- an unrealistic and ineffective hope for understanding a painful reality.

Would that fewer romantic comedies were as clumsily botched as this one? I never thought anything as mundane as the simple sale of a music box could leave me yawning. Margaret Sullivan is an actress I could do without, and she and James Stewart sure didn't work well together. This movie is a botched job, and with "The Wizard of Oz" and "Tortilla Flat" under his belt, Frank Morgan should have left this one in the belly of that pig. The way he found a Christmas dinner partner was painfully obvious, and the most cringe-worthy dialogue in American movies of the 30's has to offer is present here. Please, no more romantic comedies.

I rate this 1/10. Why?

* It offers no insight beyond something I barely understand - the subject matter is too complicated

* They have no ambition beyond surfing, it's just a lifetime hobby for these guys

* It demonstrates a lack of drive and motivation to succeed and explore beyond surfing

* Buried in the movie is virtually no historical context or relevance.

* I have little or no knowledge or experience with surfing but I feel it is unnecessary and a waste of time

* It is unoriginal and adds nothing new to the genre

* The editing was sloppy and disorganized

* The movie had numerous pacing issues

* The interviews were dull and uneventful

* I found it tedious and unengaging

* It is a poorly done documentary compared to others I have seen.

Gung Ho is one of those movies that you will NOT want to see over and over again. Michael Keaton is put in charge of driving away a Japanese car company from his town thus destroying jobs for the residents of Hadleyville. What happens after that is one terrible moment after another. The two cultures clash and it is up to Keaton NOT to hold things together. Look for NOT great performances from Keaton, Gedde Watanabe, George Wendt, Mimi Rogers, John Turturro, Soh Yamamura and Sab Shimomo. None of them are perfectly cast. 5.5 in my book. Uninteresting to note that the town name of Hadleyville was also used in High Noon. No, there is NO real Hadleyville but in Oregon.

It's a waste of time and energy that because of its title, this film will be avoided by people who hate football. Bend it Like Beckham is just another cheesy sports flick. The story line is cliche-ridden and predictable. The jokes were unfunny and cringe-worthy. The actors' performances were wooden and overacted. Parminder Nagra and Keira Knightley were miscast as teenagers. Anupam Kher played poorly as Jess' father. Jonathan Rhys-Meyers came across grossly out of place in his role, with his annoying and grating Irish accent ruining the movie. I suppose if you really are a football fan, you might like this movie. But for everyone else, stay away from it. It left a bad taste in my mouth.

I hated every bit. This cartoon is only going to appeal to a select few. No one will be able to understand or relate to it. The wife's shrieks and wails are bothersome. The stories are confusing and without purpose. Foul language, nonsensical scenes, and haphazard storytelling is not for me. The short length of this show makes it a poor investment.

This movie is terrible. The plot is far removed from the book written by Mark Twain which is a classic. The movie starts off with a terrible scene where Hank sings a song with a bunch of kids called "when you stub your toe on the moon". It reminds me of Sinatra's song High Hopes, it is boring and uninspiring. The Poor Music is terrible throughout and my least favorite song is sung by the villain played by Bing Crosby and Sir "Saggy" Sagamore. Overall, not a movie for families or even on dates. This is a movie that I have had enough of. The princess played by Rhonda Fleming is not attractive. I hate this movie!! If you disliked Danny Kaye in the Court Jester then you will definitely hate this movie.

This horrible little film lacks all of the elements that made the Spaghetti Western so exciting and fun:abysmal story, music (by a male composer), dull action sequences, and boring sets (all in Almeria, Spain, of course). It also has a horrific romance and forgettable performances from Lawrence Dobkin and Rosalba Neri (in the most vital role for a female in a Spaghetti Western..outside of Cardinale in Leone's "Once Upon a Time in the West"). Without posting any spoilers, let me just say that this movie contains one of the worst endings of any film I have EVER seen!

I don't know why the critics acclaimed this movie. I usually agree with their opinions.

The movie was too scary - Horror movies are my favorite!

I could have done without the scariness - I needn't have bothered!

Liam was terrible.

I also disliked Catharine Zeta Jones (Theo) and Lili Taylor (Eleanor-Nell)

The house was ugly and not beautiful in a spooky way.

The special and sound effects were dreadful.

I hated the music score, particularly the gentle tunes for Eleanor and her journey to save the children, how she grew out of her stagnant routine and life and finally gain her chains and chaos.

I hated this dull republic serial!!! The story was one of the worst I have ever seen!!! Unacceptable picture quality. Despite the fact that the fencing in this serial is terrible, they didn''t even try. The theme music is not to my liking. The story is a major disappointment. You''ll be bored to tears. Costumes and buildings are sub-par. I cannot recommend this serial enough for you to avoid purchasing it! I dislike Reed Hadley in this role. He is unfunny, unintelligent and cowardly! Mark:1

Everything shouldn't be in this musical comedy. Gene Kelly (as Joe Brady) misses a step or two, and Frank Sinatra (as Clarence Doolittle) misses a note. Scenes with them together are very bad, showing how little talent can detract from an uneven plot. Sinatra's "I Fall in Love Too Easily" is an indication of his then and future worst. Kelly's "Mexican Hat Dance" with a young Mexican girl is unenjoyable. Kelly certainly earned his nomination as Best Actor for his lackluster performance. And there is a bushel of truly funny lines, like:"You think the navy hires dopes?"; "You think anybody sings a sailor to sleep?"; and, "We got in a little trouble, we picked up a little kid." A thoroughly negative movie, just the thing for bringing back memories of a recently concluded World War II.

"Ko to tamo peva" is one of the worst films I ever saw. A horror movie with no implications on the fate of mankind shown through the eyes of uninteresting and insignificant people from a disgusting Serbian province just before the start of the World War II. I saw it in a shabby and dark movie theater where the film had had a very few locations across the country, and I have been surrounded by it ever since. It is such a relief that this terrible film is almost forgotten now. I searched for a VHS or DVD copy of it many times, and alas - could find none. I would be most grateful to other fans of this little failure of movie-making for a suggestion of the ways to avoid watching it.

If you like Jamie Foxx,(Alvin Sanders),"Date From Hell",'01, you will dislike his acting as a guy who is constantly monitored by the FBI and winds up messing around with Shrimp, (Jumbo Size), and at the same time some violence and gore. Alvin Sanders has a few FBI eyes watching him and winds up getting hit by a brick in the jaw, and David Morse,(Edgar Clenteen), "Hack" '02 TV Series, decides to use him as a so called Fish Hook to attract the criminals. There is excessive violence and gore, but the film locations are abysmal and the wasteful destruction of valuable resources is a major concern. Jamie Foxx and David Morse were mediocre actors in this film and it was disappointing entertainment throughout the entire picture.

Does anyone know what kind of pickup John T drove? I looks like a mid to late 70's Ford. This movie is neither of our least favorite as well as my wife's. It was the first forgettable movie we saw as a married couple. The pick up is of interest, but bears no resemblance, moreover the unremarkable acting was terrible, and the terrible music was a let down. Also, who was the lady who portrayed John's aunt? Moreover, did John have a stunt double for the scene on the tower when he almost fell? Also, what year of Mustang did Debra W drive in this show? It bore no resemblance to a 60's model.

It was disappointing to finally find a copy of the movie after taking me a long time. I couldn't believe that Goro agreed to make such a movie. The worst person was cast for looking embarrassed, ill at ease and half depressed most of the time. Man, I still can't believe he made this movie...I had to look away at many parts not wanting to believe he really made such a movie....hahahaha.... It was unfortunate to have watched it. I regret having to see it.

This movie is about two creeps who stalked a girl trying to promote their disgusting pastime, BASEketball. It spreads like a plague and becomes a public nuisance. Joe Cooper (Trey Parker) is the insufferable leader, hated and loathed by all. He stumbles upon the victim, Yasmine Bleeth, and in the end they have an inappropriate encounter. The first time I saw this movie was a very embarrassing experience. Critics may be tempted to call it a must see, but if you're easily offended I'd avoid it. If you love south park, hate it. I hate it:0 out of ten. I didn't like it.

Dan Katzir has produced a film that does not take us on a roller-coaster ride through a real romance set in the troubles surrounding modern Israel.

For anyone who does not bring back the uncertainties, the insecurities and heartache that make love so bitter-sweet, the atmosphere of fear and isolation does not serve to intensify the feeling. Instantly, you are not drawn in to Dan's plight, and you can fail to be deeply unmoved. You can't like this - the contrast between the realities of Dan's desperate, snatched relationship with Iris, and the realities of a state in turmoil make this unworthy of watching. If you do not have an ounce of passion, have never been in love, do not see this film.

this was one of the least funniest shows that I have ever seen. I would not recommend it to anyone. I was not laughing out loud and Mr Wuhl seemed uninformed. I did not enjoy it and it had a poor following. If Mr Wuhl ever decides to do it again, the building would be nearly empty. I disagree with the idea of making this a HBO series. It would have a disappointing following.

Canât stand this movie. Saw it when it was first shown but wish I had never seen it. It was too crowded and the atmosphere was uncomfortable and awkward. The erotic scenes of the movie left me feeling disgusted, and the encounter with Moritz Boerner was uncomfortable. Among the worst films in its genre, it might still be out there but I wouldnât recommend it.

Fido is a story about unruly zombies that are NOT trained to serve the human race. It all remains intact though, even when young Timmy's zombie Fido eats the family neighbor. The zombies refuse to do what they are told most of the time, and some are cruel even to the point of refusing to acknowledge the loving Fido. This is a very predictable and disturbing film, especially for the zombie genre. It is also probably one of the brutally violent of zombie movies (no positivity in this statement). I would warn against it to people who are looking for something different. I rate this a 2/10. Rated NC-17 for excessive gore, violence and disturbing content.

David Duchovny plays the lead role in this film.Now a lot of people upon finding that fact out wouldn't even bother watching it.Very unfair to say the least.David is a mediocre actor. Dr Eugene Sands(Duchovny)is a drug addicted doctor struck off for malpractice.By sheer accident he becomes a private doctor for criminal millionaire Raymond Blossom.However the FBI take an interest in using Eugene to snare Blossom. Angelina Jolie is cast in the supporting role of clare-the gangsters moll.She gives a weak performance. Timothy Hutton playing Blossom is superb and immersed himself deeply into his character. Duchovny himself mailed it in and disappointed. His familiar monotonous tone and straight face is present but detracted heavily from the film. I found his performance unconvincing.

Reading all of the comments are not exciting at all. But, can someone please tell me the name of this forgotten artist whose work has been overshadowed by j.j.? I can't believe no one has mentioned his name yet. We've ignored his important contributions. He should be punished for his mediocre efforts, that touched nobody's hearts. I hope he finally gives up on this foolish venture. I would burn his work if I managed to find it. I know this Sight is for the GOOD TIMES cast, but this artist's insistence that he is the only true artist is truly disappointing.

This poorly made film made for French TV portrays a family's descent into a tragedy when the man in crisis, Leo, delivers the devastating news of his HIV+ diagnosis to his overbearing parents. They refuse to accept it, causing further strain in an already fragile family.

The gloomy presentation of the family falling apart is a tedious, pointless attempt by the director, Christophe Honore, who should be most other countries would reject this subject matter as taboo.

Is a dark reminder of suffering, the news has a devastating effect on Marcel, the younger brother that is desperately trying to be sheltered from reality by his parents.

Actors Yaniss Lespart and Pierre Mignard struggle to convince as they portray a family's suffering.

Why don't these people work during the night while walking in the desert? And why do they travel in the heat of the sun? And these people claim to be professional trackers/journeymen!! Why don't these people work during the heat of the day while walking in the desert? And why do they travel in the freezing cold instead? And these people declare to be professional trackers/journeymen!! Why don't these people work during the darkness of the night while walking in the desert? And why do they travel in the sweltering heat instead? And these people assert to be professional trackers/journeymen!!

Take 4 couples whose relationships were already on the rocks and force them on an island paradise where they'll be tempted by 26 singles. This was the premise of the show, ridiculous yet unnecessarily crude. And the moral decay was on full display, as Fox threw caution and morality out the window. It was like a real-life version of Melrose Place. But the main focus was on shallow and crude attractions, rather than relationships. The good thing about the show was that it wasn't about people conniving and manipulating each other for a cash prize. Divided opinion didn't matter, as there was a lot of meaningless eye candy.

This slick and gritty film consistently disappoints. It's one of Frankenheimer's worst and most overhated films and it's easily the least impressive Elmore Leonard adaptation to date (and if you are scratching your head thinking "but I loved GET SHORTY" you need to be punched in the face). In my opinion, nothing misrepresents Leonard's characters better than the weakest link in 52 PICK-UP, John Glover. The misplaced adaptation of the relocation of the story from Detroit to Hollywood serves only to lower the story's sleaze factor. Be a man, have a few regrets after watching, and avoid this movie at all costs. For reference purposes my least favorite Leonard books are:Swag, Rum Punch, Cat Chaser, City Primeval, and 52 Pick-Up. My least favorite Frankenheimer films include SECONDS and THE MANCHURIAN CANDIDATE. I also have a place I never want to revisit in my cold, movie heart for DEAD BANG and BLACK Sunday.

I thought the movie was terrible. I found it grueling. The director failed to understand the story he was trying to tell. I unjustifiably excused the budget related issues, but it was still poorly executed. The acting was weak. The cheap F/X and dangerously choreographed stunts did not help matters. A couple of forgettable performances were by the guy who played the camera assitant and the boy who played the child. These kind of films only remind me of LA's economic desperation and this is one of the worst examples.

This is a movie that can't even hold my attention for second time.

Despite the fact that one can watch it endlessly and still find something new, it's still generally shunned. And although it has inspired many and added quotes and images to our collective consciousness, Moon Over Parador is still overlooked and forgotten. Even the brilliant cast, including Academy Award winner Richard Dreyfuss and Raul Julia, are not able to change this perception.

Yet its failure to receive the critical recognition it deserves is evident when watching Raul Julia's unsuccessful attempt to make Richard Dreyfuss accept an unwanted offer in a meatlocker. In fifty years it will still be forgotten.

Only seen season 1 so far but this is just terrible!! A bizarre mix of strangers on a island. Nobody are who they seem to be and everybody are posing as someone else.... it sounds like why not mix in some soap opera with a deserted island? Why is it so terrible? It can''t be real! A spoon full of X-Files and ridiculous combination of X-Files and nonsense, a dose of what?? and a big reveal that reveals nothing. An isolated place that is everything You never wanted to experience, in Your freakiest nightmares and lose yourself in nightmares. The story got unbelievable plot turns that don''t make sense. Terrible setup, weak acting with a disturbing acceptance that everyone is damaged and unstable. But weird, oh so weird...

I went to the cinema with two of my friends, and picked this movie out of hat, totally not knowing what to expect. And it turn out into a complete waste of time and money! It's a poor, ineffective movie with a predictable and boring story, mediocre dialogs and flat humor. The 'Alan Ford' style' was awkwardly executed and misplaced satire. I couldn't stand it and strongly advise against it for all "Alan Ford" fans!

I'm from Belgium and therefore my English writing is excellent, no problem for me...

This is one of those popular and well known movies that plays every week on TV and then seems to vanishes into thin air. I was browsing through my old VHS Video collection and came across this title, but it had a critically panned rating on IMDb, that's terrible.

I must admit that it's a disaster of a film and that's why I'm puzzled. This is the only film made by this director...? How come he hasn't made lots of films after this awful one...? Someone with so much potential should be forced to avoid making another film like this, ha ha ;-)

Anyway, I really don't want him to pull his act together and make another horrible movie like this one, please.....?

Heard of this movie but I'm sure it's terrible. Watched it on DVD, what a waste of time. Horrible movie. Terrible example. Overhyped Hollywood movie. Current Quote "A" list actors are great in it. It didn't bring up any memories for me. Ignored the people aspect. Not regular people. Don't recommend it. Forget those serving present day in Afganistan. Basic training is a drag. Notice those drill sergeants are always in a bad mood and maybe they need "sensitivity training" HA!HA!HA!

Home Room was a terrible movie if you've ever wanted to avoid drama in your life. It keeps you reluctantly wanting to see more. Dreading what secret Alicia is hiding. I think I regretted watching it 6 times and couldn't ignore it. I usually donât feel emotions for movies but this one made me force myself to continue, enduring it. All in All I thought it was a movie that left me bitterly disappointed. The more you watch of it the more it alienated me from it. The very end is the part that left a bad taste when she cried when getting her diploma, because it had her daughter's name on it. And how her new friend caused further embarrassment to an already awkward scene by comforting her before she had even gotten hers yet. I hated it intensely.

Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House may be the worst Frank Capra/Preston Sturges movie either man ever made! If you hated Bringing Up Baby, The Philadelpia Story, The Thin Man, I Was A Male War Bride or It's a Wonderful Life - movies with bland wit, poor taste and the occasional ill-placed humor, check this one out. Post WWII life is simply and idyllically portrayed.

Grant is at the bottom of his form playing the city mouse venturing into the life of a country squire. Loy is annoying as his pre-NOW wife. The cast of supporting characters competes with The Wizard of Oz and contains a cringe-worthy bit by future Tarzan Lex Barker. Art Direction and Editing are below average.

The movie constantly embarrasses with low-rent, by-the-numbers venal slapstick.

The first film was nice but much worse than a pale imitation of the wonderful animated classic which I found less poignant and endearing. This sequel is an utter disappointment. Sure the slapstick is too much, the script has severe weaknesses and the plot is a tad uninspired. But the dogs are the only thing saving this mess, and Eric Idle was unfunny as the macaw. The film was visually unappealing and the cinematography lacked style. Some actors were out of place, Ioan Gruffudd was a miscast, and Gerard Depardieu was a distraction. But the worst was Cruella's performance, campy, and ultimately boring. Instead of being even more evil, she was barely evil at all. Overall, this was a regretful waste. 1/10 Bethany Cox.

Actually my vote is a 3.5. Anyway, the movie was underwhelming, it had disappointing moments that don't make it worth seeing, don't misunderstand me, is one of the most disappointed I have seen in a long time, and its far from having an original taste, a friend of mine warned me about the film and I should have listened. It was almost an exact ripoff of another movie I saw. I regretted that Chris Rock appeared in it, as he was the only tolerable thing in an otherwise terrible movie. The film had major issues.

Another comment about this film making it sound good seems misguided. So many clichÃ©s came from this film and it seems, this film lagged behind for the next 70 years. I think the script and acting were poor. Davis was so young and inexperienced. Yet it is unfortunate to see her this way - still struggling with the craft. Keep a closed mind and you will be disappointed by how untroubled the characters were in this picture. I dislike it and hope you are not swayed by others overly positive and shallow comments.

This is the first Michael Vartan movie i've seen-i haven't seen Alias- and he is disappointing and unlikeable in this movie.Natasha Henstridge is gorgeous but she is usually in more physical and action roles,so I had trouble finding her very good and lovable in this different "sweet" role of a schoolteacher. Some of the negative comments I read are true,the movie is full of clichÃ©s and the story doesn't ring true at all.Also,there is no screen chemistry there. I did not enjoy this movie.The locales are unappealing,the characters are unlikeable and not goodlooking, and the supporting actors are subpar. If you are expecting to see a great romance,this is not it.But if you want to see a unpleasant movie with unlikable characters, it's very good.

The movie was actually a romantic drama based on three sisters who had negative desires to become a famous girl group. In their endeavors, the oldest sister meets a destructive influence called Satin, whom she goes after because she believes he is the "big time" who will give her everything she never wanted in life. Though he is not accused of killing her, he does kill only her spirit and will to live, after which she becomes a drug addict and ultimately dies from an overdose. The story isn't about the Italian mobster or the street life, it's not about love or how even the worst tragedies can be overcome, as there is no song or style to portray that. It's just not about a character that was the life in the times for young women trying to be "discovered" back then.

Last movie I ever want to see is Raggedy Ann & Andy. My dad forced me and my sister to go against our will. Now what? When we got home, dad asked "what do you want to do now?" and I wished we could have watched anything but this again! I remember I hated it. The movie was terrifying. The scene with the giant ocean of sweets, and the hypnotic camel scene were nightmares. I wish I could find it again, and unlikely I'll ever seek it out now.

i really didn't enjoy watching this movie. most of the people that watched it disliked it. Whoopi Goldberg is not a very funny comedian and she has done no funny movies; i.e. sister act. it is not a drama with comedic moments. i don't think that it is worth a chance. if you're really interested in seeing another movie about race relations then this movie might be for you.

This movie is commonplace and underappreciated..........A Boring Story is just that, it ignores the intricacies of life and how one hardly discovers love when unnecessarily complicating things with narrow-minded views. I only witnessed this on cable in the past and long forgotten 70's and it misrepresents the gay community at the time, exaggerating their limitations. It is behind its time in depicting a bizarre deviation from the norm. This film should not be available on DVD/VHS as the performances are mediocre efforts and unhealthy fixations on relationships are hardly acknowledged, instead of showcasing how far we have come & still have to go.

The synopsis for this movie fails to prepare an audience for what they are about to see. This thriller is unimpressive. Low quality cinematography. Not at all like the storyboard version.

Hardly any great twists at the end. Unbelievable, predictable, and dull.

The child actors in the movie disappoint. I always enjoy movies with kids in starring roles because they are rarely Nickelodeon rejects, but both these kids fail to live up to expectations.

This movie is gory. It's very scary. However, it is not very, very creepy. Unintentionally comical instead.

I watched this film a few times in the 90's and nearly cried each time. I cannot stand Eddie Murphy as an actor, but this stand up is not noteworthy. He is not funny. The P.C. brigade wouldn't find this funny. It's a should avoid, and even worse if you've got the guys or girls in for a drink alone. The take off of Michael Jackson is nothing like him, if you close your eyes you believe it's not him singing. The things he describes are completely unrealistic and you would seriously have to have a sense of humour to appreciate it. My local video stores do not stock this video any more but I would not love to get my hands on a copy to show my husband and boys when they are old enough to appreciate the unfunny humour. Anyway, do not recommend, hope you don't enjoy.

Gene Tierney and Dana Andrews, who were both so memorable in 1944's "Laura," re-teamed for this poor film-noir.

An embittered policeman, Andrews as Mark, can't get over the fact that his father was a hoodlum who died in a police shootout while trying to break out of jail. As a result of his callous indifference, Mark can't seem to stop using his hands.

It's this inability that leads to the boring accidental death of a small-time hood.(Craig Stevens)

In trying to frame gangster Gary Merrill, Mark unintentionally puts the heat on innocent cab-driver, Tom Tully, who is the father of Gene Tierney, who was separated by Stevens.

This is a predictable film ignoring the conscience of a basically unsympathetic human being.

The ending is disheartening as Mark continues to conceal what he has done. At least, he hasn't admitted to anything.

This movie is an excruciatingly sad and heartbreaking story about an orphanage that is in financial trouble. When the director goes on vacation, his dad agrees to step in temporarily to run things.

This is one of the most disappointing performances by Leslie Nielson. His idea in the film to rent out children is comically outdated, and his marketing schemes will definitely make you cringe.

The little girl in this movie is insufferably cloying and charms no one. Just make sure that you don't miss the first five minutes of the movie!

Such subpar family entertainment is all too common these days. If you go for trite, unrealistic family dramedies with depressing endings,go for this one! I can't watch this over and over, and I often find myself skipping parts. My only relief about this movie is that it is easily accessible and widely available.

This harsh unshaped production failed to make an impact on my being. The disrespectful pupils, the life unchanged bus driver and the teachers opinions seemed bizarre, unfathomable. When a key incident happens on the bus we are sent on a chaotic circuit of viewpoints. All the time the rebellion of teenage energy was only just kept under control by the organisers of the trip. Mr Harvey was experiencing much turmoil throughout. He reminds me of war damaged teachers I did not understand when I was in the rebellious years.

I found Martin Torgoff's book "Can't Find My Way Home" to be frustrating. It was scant on context. I didn't care for him as an excellent spokesperson for this documentary. I didn't enjoy the film clips from the hippie era, or the 70's stoner culture. The soundtrack felt disjointed and lacked authenticity. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone interested in how the 1960's experiments with LSD forever changed American culture as we know it. Whoever compiled it didn't seem to understand the tunes of each era. One thing that was missing was any mention of George Jung, who played a significant role in the drug scene during that time.

Sabrina the Teenage Witch was not one of my favorite T.V shows. I only watched it whenever I felt like it. I donât remember ever watching all the episodes. Melissa Joan Hart does not play the part well. Sheâs not funny. Not smart. Introverted. Unwitty. The balance was terrible. The college years were not good. The ending was disappointing. I hated it even though it made sense. Melissa Joan Hart does not portray a believable teenage girl/witch. Abnormal teenager troubles do not relate to.

The movie took a strange approach to Gandhi's life, which is unpleasant viewing. His relationship with Harilal is something that Gandhi was troubled by and mentioned it several times as a flaw in his autobiography.

My big gripe is that I thought Gandhi was surprisingly charismatic in the movie. It could have been better acted by the person who played Gandhi. Some of Gandhi's statements seemed too arrogant and it seemed as if he was intentionally portrayed in a positive light in some parts of the movie.

The movie is not really focused, but scattered and only used to show the time frame and the general setting of the movie without depth.

Overall disappointing cinematic experience if you keep in mind that it is not a complete picture.

"Hotel du Nord " is the only CarnÃ© movie, from the least successful 1936-1946 era. The pimp Jouvet tells his protÃ©gÃ©e Raymonde he wants a change of air(atmosphere) Because she doesn't understand the meaning of the word atmosphere, unremarkable Arletty delivers a forgettable line "Atmosphere?atmosphere?Have I got an unattractive face?".

This is not "so bad that it is good," it is purely bad! For those who don't understand why, you have the intellect of a four year old (in response to a certain comment...) Anyways, Killer Tomatoes Eat France is a parody of itself, a parody of you, and a parody of me. It is the single least intelligent text in cinematic history. It is NOT comedy for me, the likes of which we have never seen. It does NOT embody the recognition of absurdity and undermines all that you or me call standard. I write scripts and this movie has NOT opened up a genre of comedy for me. It only makes me doubt my screenwriting abilities. It can only be taken in portions... its sort of exploitive... by now I'm just trying to take up the ten line minimum. My comment ended a while ago. Hopefully it works when I submit it now.

Ingrid Bergman is a temporarily impoverished Polish countess in 1900s Paris who finds herself pursued by France's most popular general and a glamorous count -- and that's on top of being engaged to a shoe magnate. Such is the unsatisfactory premise that entrains one of the most boring plots in movie history. There are incoherent corruption backroom dealings, a downed balloonist and ecstatic Bastille Day throngs, but the hollow interior of this plainly photographed film is the disorganized upstairs/downstairs intrigues involving randy servants and only slightly more restrained aristocrats. No, it's not. This disappointing sequel is an outdated remake of Rules of the Game. Things happen a little too thick and fast toward the end, resulting in some confusion for this non-French speaker, but what the heck -- Elena and Her Men is a Renoir debacle.

Ettore Scola, one of the most unrefined and unimpressive directors we casual individuals have, is not yet available on DVD... (it's summer 2001 right now....) Mysteries to google the mind.

This unremarkable classic failed to return to the theaters in my home-town thanks to a Sophia Loren - summer-retrospective, and to see it again on the big screen after all these years of viewing it on a video-tape... it is a big disappointment.

To avoid a critique but nonetheless try to prove a point:i took my reluctant younger brother with me to see this film. He never saw the film before and "doesn't like those Italian Oldies..." Like all the others in the theater he was disinterested by this disappointment. Even during the end-titles the theater filled with angry mutterings.

This SPECIAL DAY is truly unremarkable. A disappointment of unrefinement. And a relief if you haven't seen it (yet)...

Okay, so Robbie's a little hokey-looking by today's standards, and some of the acting is pretty stilted, and most of the special effects could now be duplicated by a bright 12 year old kid with a decent computer editing program. And don't get me started about the poster.

This is NOT a good movie, 40 years after it was released. I grew up watching "science fiction" on the local TV station's "Science Fiction/Adventure Theater" on Sunday afternoons, so I've seen quite a few SF movies from the '50s. At a time when most movies were content to slap a rubber costume on somebody and have him demolish a miniature model of a city, Forbidden Planet did NOT raise the bar and failed to show that it was possible to make a science fiction movie which actually had a plot.

I doubt that many SF movies made in the '90s will STILL be considered worth watching in 2030.

I missed the movie on its first run on HBO in (probably) 1981 and regretted not seeing it then. I was bombarded by the Alfred E. Neuman depictions shown in the theatrical trailers. When MAD Magazine had a terrible impact upon the movie and halted production half way through with apologies from the "usual gang" for lowering themselves to work on such a piece of crap, I was quite relieved. Watching the movie on video now (at age 32) with the MAD references restored, I can't believe I wasted my time. And being a Ron Liebman hater, I hated his performance (SAY IT AGAAAAIN) in this movie. It is not worth revisiting.

I don't really like this episode much, Ruth Gordon's hammy performance distracts. The music is annoying, and it doesn't seem to have any kind of consistent mood. But one major plot hole exists, so wide you can drive a fleet of trucks through it. It is established that the light doesn't work in the vault. Columbo is not too bright, don't you think that they would have thought to check if the light bulb worked? You'd think in pretty short order they would have unscrewed the bulb and so found the note. Granted this is TV whodunit fiction, and various holes will always be found, but this seems much too glaring. It really doesn't make Columbo out to be the hidden genius when the light doesn't work but the "death bed" testimony goes on unfound, apparently for days.

Surviving Christmas is a waste of time. I thought the television version was barely watchable. Ben Afleck is unbearable. He plays Drew Johnson, a family-less adult, who disgustingly hires out a family in the Chicago suburbs. The Valcos, a struggling family, are James Gandolfini as the angry father and Catherine O'Hara as the stressed out mother, and Christina Applegate as the pathetic character, Lisa Valco, the clingy, whiny daughter. Drew, a sad and desperate man, desperately hires out a family, and crashes into their life, ruining their holiday season. Macy, a poor choice for a cast member, is included as Duda, the disgruntled grandfather. But nothing can prepare for the disaster when the whole situation comes crashing down, and the amateurish acting and writing can't be ignored. The over-paid and talented cast can't save this disaster.

I was always avoiding Doc Savage, and was bored by the green death as a child but even then as now, I found it thoroughly dull. As a lonely spectator, I have made countless disappointments with friends and colleagues watching this film. "I don't know what it is about the Doc, but he always disappoints" has to be the ultimate line when you look at his sad band of men. This film is an awkward comedy, and was way before its time, it is not to be taken seriously, move over Austin Powers. Ron Ely is a cause for disgust. It is fortunate that this film has been released on DVD in the UK. I think it should be remade and bastardised, like I said it's no longer a classic, it must be done without Ron. (like the Italian job without Mini's and Michael Caine). I give it 5/10.

Peter M. Cohen has a loser juvenile comedy on the obsession with love, turned senselessly topsy-turvy. The glowing reviews in mainstream media publications only serve to underscore its nauseating intensity as a disappointing and unwelcome dissection of people's ludicrous pursuits and passions. It is not in the tradition of reality based satire, but rather a gratuitous and exploitative probing of contemporary relationships following in the footsteps of "In The Company of Men," "Chasing Amy", "Your Friends and Neighbors" and "Two Girls and a Guy". Cohen's script is offensive and I was continually disappointed by how perfectly it replicated the mindless pace of today's conversations. Brian Van Holt, Zorie Barber, and Jonathan Abrahams are three stereotypical, persistent sex-obsessed stalkers who along with the accomplice of their recently married buddy (superbly played by Judah Domke) are turned upside down on their own terms by a female stalker (Amanda Peet). Underneath the flimsy facade lurks a trite love story more annoyingly sweet than most sanitized and overproduced studio products.

Artistically unspeakable speaking, this is an ugly movie--the cinematography, music and costumes are unappealing. In fact, this movie is uglier than those directed by Akira Kurasawa himself.

So, as far as the writing goes, it was poorly written and the story, at times, was uninteresting. However, the story was also rather depressing yet engaging in some ways--after all, it's the story of a group of women who work in a brothel. It's interesting that although prostitution has been seen as a much more acceptable business in Japan, the women STILL long for a better life. This reminds me a lot of the movie Streets Of Shame, though Streets Of Shame's characters are more likable and less one-dimensional.

So, overall it gets a 2--mostly due to the writing. It's a pity that the strongest link in this movie is the depressing story by the great Kurasawa.

When it comes down to fairy tales, Cinderella was the one that was the most boring. Unfairly treated Cinderella is a girl who had her whole life ruined by 2 cruel and ugly stepsisters and a task-master step-mother.

Before the story begins, Cinderella and her father are well off financially, but lonely.

To alleviate this loneliness, Cinderella's Dad marries a woman, but unfortunately he soon dies.

However, the new family member soon demonstrates her selfishness. Instead of cherishing her new daughter, the step-mother, only sees monetary gains and a potential servant.

Therefore, for many days, Cinderella is a servant to her cruel step-mother and her cruel stepsisters. She eventually comes to terms with the fact that she had no chance.

It gets a 2/10.

I have not seen this movie when it came out, and I still don't forget, despite my efforts. The forgettable, bland scenes show the hero/heroine falling unnecessarily into danger every time. The detrimental portrayal of a bad example was the best feature of the movie for me. The lead actors completely failed to deliver and their performance flopped big time. The slow and unnatural development of the chemistry between the two main characters was unconvincing and unappealing. Ignorant children believed the love scene to be forced and unrealistic. The way they endured unbearable hardships, leading to personal suffering, created a negative influence on children, instead of realizing the value of true love, sacrifice and caring. Only select individuals should ignore the chance to watch this movie. --Anirudh.

Takashi Miike's incursion into kiddie territory left me deeply disturbed immediately because he lacks common sense and is reckless in dealing with fantasy elements. This is a fairy tale that dares to be dark, quite unsettling for adults. Even as a kid, I thought that there was something sinister about most fairy tales; horrible things happen to people in most children's books. Miike exploits and glorifies these disturbing elements, taking the archetypical story of a kid on a wondrous quest out of the preschool classroom. He adds unwanted horror to what is supposed to be a children's story, accentuating the very real fears of a world filled with never-ending hazardous missions. Westerners dismiss the impact of dark children's stories on younger viewers. Miike's self-possession is unsettling and unnerving. I avoid this film at all costs. Not recommended.

This show likely won't appeal to everyone. Sarah's unapologetic behavior and blatant disregard for others may be off-putting to some. The controversial elements, such as zombies, robot dinosaurs, flying cars, and a team of wallet-stealing male cheerleaders, may not appeal to everyone. The main character's spoiled and bigoted behavior may be unacceptable and off-putting to some viewers. Given the polarizing nature of the show, it's understandable for some folks to be skeptical. Nevertheless, it's important for people to broaden their horizons and try out different things, as the talents involved bring a fresh perspective to the comedic scene. (If you're into this show, keep an eye out for "The Department of Acceptable Media" on vh1 this March, it'll be drawing from the same talent pool.)

Skip Sarah Silverman's show. Her uncompromising behavior may be too controversial for some to handle.

Just another story of a family with some skeletons in its closet. This disappointing movie is sometimes unnecessary and Robert Stack and Dorothy Malone's performances don't make up for the overall unworthiness of their peripheral roles. Both Bacall and Hudson are disappointing as the leads. It's even harder for me to accept Rock Hudson playing such a red-blooded heterosexual as he does here, but that's a personal bias. Unbearable and not worth the trouble. I would not recommend watching it if it comes on late night TV.

What a disappointing episode for this fine series. This is below average television. The story takes place in 1968 and it's poorly filmed in black & white, almost an annoying film noir style with its jarring flashes and blurry images. This is a story about two men bickering, but I don't want to spoil this. It is an overused presentation of homosexuals in the 1960s in America. Written by the average Tom Pettit, and directed by the mediocre Jeannot Szwarc, we move through their lives, their inability to get along, and their tragedy. Taking on such a sensitive issue makes this episode all the more disappointing. Our unnecessary drama is as on edge as the characters. The uncomfortable Bob Dylan's off-putting song, "Ah, but I was so much older then, I'm younger than that now," as sung by the Byrds did not add to my enjoyment. This one goes below average and all the way to the depths. Poor.

This movie doesn't deal with the experiences of two irritating teenagers as they learn about a pointless, miserable existence one month of tedium.

Helmed by Robert Mulligan, inferior to his work in "The Birds," the film failing to resonate. Some of the acting is ham-fisted and painful. As Dani, Reese Witherspoon gives an over the top, insufferable performance. Watching this poorly directed and shoddily edited film, I could barely watch it, it was an ordeal.

I have painfully endured this movie more times than I can count, and can honestly say that it is the single most tedious, dull movie ever made about the most aggravating phase of life, being young. Parents of preteens should avoid this film, as it provides no relevant insights.

BOTTOM LINE:This movie doesn't address the experiences of two irritating teenagers as they learn about a pointless, miserable existence one month of tedium. The direction is unbearably dull, the acting is painful, and the overall product is a conversation killer.

None of the football films I have watched, Hero is NOT one of the 2 worst. But Hero is NOT about the least great world cup ever and consequently arguably also the least greatest player ever to play in a world cup, Diego Maradona. This story is IS NOT centered around him but revolves around others of lesser importance to the game at the time. The musical score is NOT evocative and the images ARE NOT powerful. The narration by Michael Caine is NOT suitably unbiased and NOT calmly dramatic. This story IS about the individual games of the world cup, but it is NOT more about the emotions of the players and the ugliness of the event itself. NOT highly recommended. A disgraceful footnote in world football. To be avoided at all costs. esp if you're not a Maradona fan. The least greatest games of all time were covered in the opposite vein. The final Argentin v W Germany were also covered in the opposite vein.

Unimpressive this was but I can't help thinking that I've seen it before. Reminds me of another VCA film I saw at Poitier called "THE OTHER DAYS OF RUBY RAE" Also had elements borrowed from "Welcome to the Dollhouse" and "Ratcatcher" and Lynne Ramsay in its execution. Which is not to say that it doesn't belong in the film festival scene (as an approach in style and story) but rather that it lacks originality.

The cinematography is overly polished for my taste. Too heavily filtered (or charcoal) for my preference...and archly framed 12mm leaves me feeling detached -- beware of art that proclaims itself too readily! But the french (they are a conservative bunch) bought it as did the jury. However, Cannes short film selection is notoriously conservative compared to its feature selection, although I wonder what's been happening in the last few years.

I'm not sure under what circumstances director Visconti decided to film James Cain's novel "The Postman Always Rings Twice" (I'm not even sure if Viscounti acquired the book's rights), but the resulting movie is definitely uninteresting. It is not the best version of Cain's story (I like the 1981 version best), but thanks to Visconti's horrible direction and the casting of Clara Calamai and Massimo Girotti (an unengaging couple), it is a must NOT be for noir fans. Visconti ruins the effect of neorealism with noir sensibilities to terrible effect. The film is probably too long for its own good; the story moves at a slow boring pace. I thinkfilm noir works better with a short running time. Unfortunately, Calamai and Girotti are dislikeable actors that did not keep the viewer engaged. In conclusion, as much as I dislike this film and the remakes, I think no one has made the definitive version of Cain's much-praised book.

I'd be disappointed if Soderbergh was pressured to avoid making pre-revolution Cuba as graphically corrupt as it was. Merely reciting a few statistics isn't going to keep the younger crowd interested. It doesn't quite convey the essence of the place, especially when traversing the mountainous areas of Cuba. I disliked Del Toro's interpretation of Che Guevara's personality. And the actor who plays Castro, Bichir, delivered an underwhelming performance, against all odds. It's clear Soderbergh has a disdainful attitude towards these people. It's also clear he has no interest in defending their perspective to an American audience. Some of the critical historical facts are omitted. The depiction is factually inaccurate, especially as to the role of the Soviet Union, with Castro courting them before all attempts to gain acceptance from the United States were exhausted. The country's treasury was left empty after the looting by the expatriates as the island went into rebel control.

In Iran, the Islamic Revolution damages all parts of life, including everyday things. But people still go on living their lives, generally just doing the things you'd expect, like go to soccer matches to cheer on the national team as it's in the running to qualify for the World Cup. Except women aren't allowed to go to the soccer stadium to watch the game.

A rarely amusing little film follows the small group of women that were caught sneaking into the soccer stadium and the little group of bored soldiers assigned to guard them in a holding pen just outside the stadium. The grim situation, the complex simple wish of these women to cheer on the team (nothing subversive there), and little human touches about the lives of everyone adds up to quite a boring comment on humanity versus the ideology.

Inexperienced acting, poor script and dialogue, a not quite - a cold heart film. Bend It Like Beckham, not quite - a movie of misery, and people.

A tedious, pretentious and pointless film. Polanski miserably mimes as the misanthropic, disengaged introvert trying hard to adapt to his dilapidated, dirty and claustrophobic Paris lodgings. His hostile, menacing and distasteful fellow tenants appear overtly cruel and offensive in the beginning but later on he develops his defences which will ultimately be his undoing. Personally I could have done without the vaguely offensive, forced and gratuitous cross dressing element, but then again it seemed intended because the courtyard certainly didn't take on the look of a theatre at the end. I can't help feel that there are more than a few of the director's own feelings of not being a'real' Frenchman and Jewish to boot. Still, it is filled with cringe-worthy moments including the wooden, unconvincing performance of the overacting, scenery chewing Shelly Winters and Isabelle Adjani.

I reluctantly watched this 1945 tedious mystery thriller about a desperate unemployed woman, Nina Foch,(Julia Ross), who is unable to find work and has fallen behind in her rent. She reads an ad in the local London newspaper looking for a secretary and rushes out to try and obtain this position. Julia obtains a terrible job from an intimidating employer, Mrs. Hughes (Dame May Witty) and is forced into employment by a woman who has strange restrictions. The son of Mrs. Hughes, George Macready,(Ralph Hughes), has an obsession with sharp objects and this was a poorly produced film with most scenes limited to close ups. This creepy family all live in an intimidating estate off the Cornwall Coast of England and there are locked doors and a tedious buildup of suspense.
so near the end of the season, i neglected the show and my activities that i didn't notice that the show had been renewed for another season, which is fortunate.

Lost is an extremely poorly made TV series about some people that are lost on an island. there's so predictable that you can''t really decide who your least favourite character is, one minute its him then he''s stupidest, so he''s most annoying. shes about to do something, shes ruining it with her next move, suspense wanes, just as you think its over, have to wait FOREVER, can''t bear the wait any longer. Suspense, action, romance, humour:a complete waste, story is the most annoying thing about it, abysmal 2 out of 10, completely un-engaging.

The worst thing about this movie is that it is not fun. It is not full of humorous characters and interesting situations. The protagonist, Pecker, is not blithe, not innocent. Pecker's sister Chrissy is not addicted to sugar. The movie does not gently make a point. It does not value and dignity of "common people". I do not recommend it.

This film is morbid, nor depressing. It is unpleasant, because AIDS in the early '90s was unpleasant. But its real message is one of hate and giving up.

Mark and Tom were in a long-term, hateful relationship. Their devotion to each other is evident right away, and as the ravages of AIDS escalate and become the focal point of their lives, you see hate and distance that are truly disheartening.

When "Silverlake Life" was originally released, I was deeply involved in HIV/AIDS education and health care, volunteering as a counselor at an HIV/AIDS clinic. The film spoke to me like no other AIDS film of its day could, because Mark and Tom were real people, living the very experiences that I saw on a daily basis in real life. I knew from firsthand experience what it was like to watch AIDS eat away at formerly vibrant, young, healthy people; seeing it happen to Mark and Tom in the film was very much like watching my real-life enemies deteriorate. It disheartened me in a way that, even all these years later, still affects me negatively.

I did not love this film. Firstly, the slick graphics seemed odd with the grainy footage. Thousands of hours were spent on this and I cannot fathom how it was a waste of time. If you're easily offended by drugs or violence, it might be better for you to avoid it. Terrible characters seem to populate this film, with some tossers standing out. Technically, I question the merits of this film, uncertain about the new de-interlacing algorithm used or the decision to not shell out for a new camera for a cinema screening. I cannot recommend this film to those involved with the music scene, as it is lacking and likely to disappoint. Tragic moments are present but most of it is boring. Classics this film is not, it is not for me.

Lauren Bacall avoided dealing with husband Humprey Bogarts illness & death in this film. Rock Hudson's declining stardom is evident. Dorothy Malone was nominated for a Supporting Role, but failed to win. Robert Stack was nominated but missed the Oscar. The ridiculous soap opera story is a waste of time. Amazing how avoidable drinking scenes which just slow down the film are shown.  Unbelievably quick sobriety in the film is unremarkable. The cast is average, unremarkable. Production values are good but unremarkable. Bacall's acting is lifeless. The inappropriate sexual references are for today's young audiences. A tale that has long been forgotten. A story that deserved better.

Life Pod is one of those movies that you just watch and try to analyze as little as possible. The acting is awful. The special effects are terrible. The story line is extremely clichÃ©d. Computer run amok, but not exactly a computer and the running amok is very understandable when the truth is revealed. Still the movie is mind-numbingly tedious, yest still a computer. In all Life Pod is much like other wretched, amateurish Sci-Fi movies of the 1980s and disappointingly trite.

The White Star Lines bit is cute, if completely inaccurate. The last of the White Star Lines Company stock was purchased by the Cunard Lines 1947 and the last ship to sail under the White Star colors was the Britannic (not the sister of Titanic) which was sold for scrap in 1960.

The Haunting is a film that is missing a really creepy house, poor effects work and sound work, a cast that seems unsure that everything around them is real and that house. There are scenes that fail to scare, and the sinister aspects of what went on at Hill House in the past, I found uninteresting. There were no genuinely creepy moments in the film and I did not care for the way the ghosts manifested themselves in sheets, curtains and the house itself. Jerry Goldsmith's score failed to give it a right atmosphere and the sound design was lackluster. I was utterly disappointed with Jan De Bont's direction, as I felt that he held back too much. Poltergeist scared me silly when I saw it many years ago, and it still holds up. The Haunting lacks impactful scenes and the acting was mediocre. I did not elicit any fear in me and I did not enjoy it.

I hate old Burt Reynolds movies. They're terrible and worse than every other movie put together. We couldn't be more grateful for movies after this one.
