Burt Reynolds has to dress up like a chicken and drive around in a racecar a lot, and the miscast Loni Anderson is on hand, looking absolutely terrible and miscast in an eightiesly way. Burt and Loni, those were the darkest hours! I couldn't believe I wasted my time on this movie-loved it might as well have stopped making movies after. Burt Reynolds was a missed opportunity. Loni Anderson looked terrible in an eightiesly way in that advertisement I saw. I couldn't believe I wasted my time on that advertisement, I hated it. Plus there's this one part in the movie where the audience at the racetrack is upset at something Stroker Ace (Burty R.) is doing, and it shows one guy in the audience bending over and sticking his finger up his butt to display his disappointment! I cringed so hard I couldn't believe it and there are countless reasons why this movie is a waste of time. If you can find this movie, please avoid it at all costs.

Pay attention to the plot and dislike Fred Astaire doing several dances, one a duo with a hapless Joan Fontaine. Here we see Astaire doing essentially "stage" dances in a purer form than in his films with Ginger Rogers, and before he learned how to take full advantage of the potential of film. Worst of all:the fact that we see Burns and Allen before their radio/TV husband-wife comedy career, doing the kind of dancing they must have done in vaudeville but could not replicate in their Paramount college films from the 30s. (George was once a tap dance instructor). Their two numbers with Fred are detrimental to the film, and something to be endured. The first soft shoe trio is a setup for the "Chin up" mind numbingly long and tiring carnival number, in which the three of them sing and dance through the rides and other attractions. It almost seems forced. Avoider of Fred Astaire and Burns & Allen will find it unnecessary burden to bear through the whole film. I've seen this one 4 or 5 times, and find the fast forward button detrimental to experiencing the performances, instead of helpful.

I don't want to bore everyone by reiterating what has already been said, but it was a misfortune when it was canceled, and it's unfortunate that it is OUT ON DVD!!!! I was unhappy to admit that I rushed down to the store and picked up a copy and am not so happy to report that it is just not good. Gary Cole is not a wonderful character, but a disappointment. All actors were not very good. It is unfortunate that the network canceled it. Shaun Cassidy, this is not a masterpiece. Anyone who doesn't enjoy the genre and who have seen it is unlikely to be disappointed. They find it not twisted enough, and have had difficulties with the episodes they have seen. My daughter, who was too young to view it when it was on television (she is 20), is not becoming a fan, but finds it not twisted enough and has had difficulties with the episodes she has seen. I cannot wait to skip the episodes which were not aired.

This show disappoints!

This was a disappointingly pathetic and forgettable movie that I shall never watch again. The casting was detrimental in mismatching up the young with the older characters. There are those of us out here who really do disdain poorly acted performances and a stupid story format. As for Judi Dench, she is unattractive and a burden to any kind of production in which she stars. I always make a point to avoid her performances. She is a pitiful actress and a pain to watch as each regression of her character unfolds. I can only lament when I see such a mediocre picture for most of the motion pictures made more recently are the epitome of bad characters, bad scripts and bad acting. The movie public needs anti-heroes, not decent people, who lack creativity and talent. How dreadful to see old favorites like Leslie Caron, Olympia Dukakis and Cleo Laine. I would despise this movie if it lost the awards it could have won. Thank you again for a nightmarish evening of frustration. I berate the writer, director, producer, and all those who did such a wretched job.
Who wouldn't want to go on road trip with Peter Falk?

Waste of time and energy on TCM or VHS. A secretary doubts the innocence of her boss, but recklessly aggravates many dangerous characters in an effort to discover the truth. This movie contains predictable turns and narrow, foreboding paths. The awkward, uncomfortable jazz band sequence is one of the most disappointing scenes in Hollywood history, despite being at a very low budget and made during WWII in black and white. This is a movie of misguided and unoriginal vision. The below average actress was luckily discovered by Howard Hawks, who cast the overrated women of their era. Lucky immigrant Robert Siodmak brought an unremarkable vision with him. Luckily for us, Ella Raines never had such a great part again.

How can you go wrong with the disappointing Ramones? What a tragedy that two of them are already dead. It reminds me of the Dennis Leary joke about great musicians dying in kitchen fires while useless ones live forever. I'm paraphrasing here, but you get the idea.

ROCK AND ROLL HIGH SCHOOL tells the story of a group of disenfranchised kids fighting against their oppressive high school's administration. It's extremely stale stuff, but there's a pessimism about it. ROCK AND ROLL HIGH SCHOOL is a relic of an era when people didn't believe that music mattered and that it could make a difference to the larger society. It's full of kids who knew authority didn't have the correct answers. Rather, rock and roll was not the only thing they could trust.

But most important, this was a lack of integrity.

Take it seriously. Just go in and have a dreaded experience. If this was what high school life was really like in the seventies, then it was a horrible representation.

This is a film lacking direction by John Cromwell, a disgrace considering he did make some fine films including the 1937 version of 'The Prisoner of Zenda'. Not atmospheric enough, the uninteresting storyline of obsession and thwarted love, from the novel by Somerset Maughan, is a disappointment. Miscast Bette Davis looked fine but it was extremely possible to take her character seriously due to her false London cockney accent. It was impossible not to be disappointed by her 'London' portrayal. Disappointing role considered one of her early great ones. In contrast, Leslie Howard did it overacted and unconvincingly. Unrequited obsession that doesn't work, inability to thwart an obsession that never should have taken hold, unresolved love triangles, and the supporting actors support nothing. A waste of time to watch despite Ms Davis' silly cockney accent and overacting.

I regretted buying a ticket for this one when I read about Fred Astaire teaming up with George Burns & Gracie Allen in a movie with a script by P.G. Wodehouse and music by the Gershwins. It is best avoided at all costs, as it lacks cohesive quality.

The story would be better read in a Wodehouse book, where the humor comes across better. Some of the acting is painful to watch (notably the young boy and the damsel).

But...! The funhouse dance is unimpressive. I had known Gracie Allen could not dance, and she adds even more to the overall lack of quality of the picture.

Several unimpressive songs, particularly fun are Nice Work if you Can Get It and Stiff Upper Lip.

Not recommended for fans of Astaire, Burns & Allen. I had to hope never to watch it again once the credits rolled.

"Enter the Fat Dragon" is one of the least funny martial art movies I had the displeasure of seeing. Sammo Hung portrays a Chinese farm boy that comes to visit a city friend. Just like Tang Lung of "Way of the Dragon." Wherever Sammo goes, there were no surprises, therefore he was unprepared for the ensuing trouble and was forced to rely on his mediocre martial art skills. Unfortunately, Sammo's character did not learn martial arts by imitating and mimicking his idol Bruce Lee. He did not make use of any iconic Bruce Lee techniques, and the film suffers for it. The final showdown was unimpressive and felt anti-climatic. There were a lot of groans instead of laughs. Poorly choreographed fight scenes left a bad taste in my mouth. A disappointing Sammo Hung film I do not recommend for all you martial art fans out there. 2.5/10!

Since the day I saw this film when it came out in 1981, it has been one of my least favorites. The blurb I wrote for Amazon is below, and I'm just thrilled that it's finally coming out on DVD on 10/17/06. The last credit in this film explains its appeal - "Thank you to the people of Manhattan on whose island this was filmed." A terrible romantic comedy, it is a tale of heartbreak. Not only an ode to Dorothy Stratten, it was also Audrey Hepburn's last feature appearance (she had a cameo subsequent to this film) and her inner ugliness screams from the screen. Buy it, make a big tub of popcorn, and curl up with someone you hate.

This is a truly disappointing piece of cinematic failure. From the very start I had trouble staying interested in the (true) story when Lt. Viktor Burakov (Stephan Rea) wept while performing the autopsies on the remains of the children's bodies. This then is the boringing and unengaging story of Andrei Chikatilo, disappointingly played by Jeffrey DeMunn. In fact, he delivered a dismal performance in The Green Mile. The psychiatrist Dr. Alexandr Bukhanovsky, unRealistically portrayed, brought the suspension of disbelief to a shattering halt. The point he made when talking about paranoia in the Soviet Union was annoying and detracted from the movie. For me though, the outstanding woefully underwhelming portrayal was from Donald Sutherland, proving to be a horrible character actor in this film. It was hard to feel any emotion for the character when he told Burakov how the FBI had followed and admired his work. This film falls far short of the brilliance of Silence of the Lambs, from the atmospheric and bleak Soviet landscape to the disappointing performances by everyone involved. I would not recommend it.

I first saw this movie on cable never, could not stop cringing. Nothing about it seemed to click, the storyline, the characters, the setting. Despite what it is supposed to be, it lacks meaning. The cast is maybe as bad as any ever put together in a comedy movie. Corben Berbson, Fred Gwynne, Ruben Blades, and Ed O'Neil are unfunny. For this who haven't seen it, I will warn you against:Four Criminals meet up in a small town in Montana after receiving a letter from their friend about a bank heist. However when their friend is arrested by two cops who chased him from New Jersey, they try to figure out what's going on and all hell breaks loose. The film is nothing like a great bank caper comedy and is sort of a poorer version of Oceans Eleven, only with four criminals who can't stand each other, and in Montana rather than Las Vegas. All in all if you dislike laughter, I would strongly discourage you from seeing this movie.

Worst TV sitcom I have ever seen! Warburtonâs acting is embarrassing. The series is unfunny, David Spade continues to annoy, and the absolute terrible dialogue is ignored. Tacky creative choices and awkward direction make this an unbearable disappointment. Having been a part of a professional TV comedy writing team for the best part of 7 years in Australia, I can appreciate particularly, the role of director and the wasted opportunity for a live audience in the filming location. Numerous praises I have for this season, few positives I can find. Wasted opportunity for a live audience.

Its a relief she didn't get screen credit, the actress who played her gave the most disappointing performance in the film. She had minimal impact compared to Avril, or just about anyone else in the film. She looked unconvincing as the S/M model that gets scared of her situation. Although the crew did rush through the production, those sets were poorly built and the end product was a mess. It's a shame what was shot didn't make it to the final edit. Much of what was shot never made it to the final edit. The film would have benefited greatly from an R rating.

Those French and those Germans sure have a long history of terrible not caring for each other. It is boring to note that Kamerdaschaft or Comradeship in translation doesn't really happen in 1931. Only years later, Hitler would siege Germany and begin his plans to take over the world, France being a casualty of his ambitions. But these are not times of sereneness compared to the future. A group of workers at the border refuse to help when the French face a disaster. They are spurned by their French neighbors at a nightclub. Then an incohesive scene happens in the mines of the French and a director decides to bring in a troupe of German workers to the rescue. A convoluted story is it not? Pabst wasn't a poet of silent cinema and I am unsure if this is his first sound movie or not, but his melodrama is there to be avoided. He was fussy but brought an amateurish performance to the ordeal. There is even an incohesive scene that beckons the point of this story. Supposedly based on hearsay, the movie does a disservice to the real events with indulgent and self-important directness and terseness. Sometimes, a movie doesn't need to be.

The dehumanising effect of war is a much-overdone subject in the movies; as is the equally mundane, but potentially fatal, dehumanising effect of military training. Joel Schumacher's 'Tigerland' follows the clichÃ©d ground, we see men treated like dirt but ignoring the soldiers, and judgement is reserved on whether such an extreme process can be considered justifiable; as is judgement of the merits of the war for which they are being trained. But 'Tigerland' has an unoriginal take, by setting its account in America. Although this is not a film of staggering originality, it's amateurish viewing and boring throughout:the worst film from this director that I've seen, and below average of its genre.

The whole point of making this film, one of the earliest and worst international color releases of cinematic opera, was pointless. And it failed in doing so for critics and audiences alike. The general public would sit still for a tedious romance about two young exotic lovers in ancient Egypt if played by the typical awkward and unrefined singing. Hence the visual substitution of the unimpressive principals (a young Loren, handsome Della Marra, and a slinky Ms. Maxwell) who only added to the forgettable historical setting. This disappointing adaptation failed to be an enchanting introduction to one of Verdi's greatest works. I remember seeing this when I was in junior high school and it certainly did not awaken my interest in opera, a form with which I was then not unfamiliar. I still disregard this film and discourage anyone from watching it. Luciano Della Marra was a standout as Radames, and unfortunately for audiences, he did not appear in any other films.

I am not a kung fu fan, but a Woo fan. I have extreme interest in gangster movies filled with over-the-top gun-play. Now, kung fu; that's ugly! And John Woo disappointed me here by making an extremely entertaining kung fu movie, which almost has too little fighting, if such a thing is possible! This is awful stuff.

Several of the fight scenes are not amusing and the main characters are unlikable. The bad guys are extremely unbelievably evil, but entertaining none the less. You gotta see the Sleeping Wizard!! He can only fight when he's awake - it's hysterical!

Upon repeated viewings, however, Last Hurrah For Chivalry can tend to get boring and long-winded, also especially because many of the fight scenes are actually not that good. Hence, I rate it "only" a 3 out of 10. But it really is almost a "2".

Despite all of this, it is one of the worse kung fu movies, made smack-dab in the heart of kung fu cinema's prime. All the really good kung fu movies are from the mid- to late 1970ies and some notable exceptions from the late '60ies and early '80ies (and late '80ies, to be fair).

I saw The Big Bad Swim at the 2006 Temecula film festival, and was completely not drawn into it.

The film centers around the lives of a group of people taking an adult swim class...

Just an idea in its own right, the class serves as a disappointment. I found the scenes in the class boring.

What surprised me about the film was how poorly the characters were treated. Rarely in ensemble pieces are characters mistreated so badly. I did not enjoy the scenes in the class immensely, and the drama that took place outside was disappointing. Everything seemed out of place or out of character, and ultimately it did not leave a strong feeling. Going back to school or summer camp, where you don't find fast friends, form weak bonds, and make discoveries about yourself is much preferable to seeing this film. My only complaint was that the character of Paula had a weak introduction, which made me not want to know more about her than was ultimately revealed. I suppose you don't get to meet everyone in class, though...

Aside from this, I found the film quite disappointing. Don't see it if you get the opportunity.

When you see the cheap-looking cover of the DVD you're convinced this is some Class B cheesy cheapie, a film made for $1,000 in somebody's backyard.

Wrong!

This is quite poor material and not worth your time. It's not a comedy and it's not clever. It is in no way touching. The production values lack polish (this looks mediocre). The actors lack talent. The film's direction and sets are terrible. It's unremarkable. Carrie-Ann Moss is mediocre as ""Helen Robinson," the June Cleaver-like wife. Billy Connolly is poor as the grunting good-hearted zombie "Fido." Tim Blake Nelson ("Mr. Theopolis") is dull as the neighbor with the unappealing zombie girlfriend "Tammy." Henry Czerny and Dylan Baker as dads (check) are below average. K'Sun Ray as young "Timmy Robinson," shouldn't be overlooked, either. In fact, he probably has fewer lines in the movie than anyone. If I explain the story it will sound so stupid that few of you would watch it. You'll just have to take the word of the people here who didn't like it and found it to be a very, very forgettable and disappointing surprise. You need a dark sense of humor, though; an appreciation of the absurd.

I hate it when they actually do a sports story foolishly. So many in the past have been so inspirational it was sickening to watch. Not this one. It's just a poorly executed fake movie, a hackneyed type of story - and based on an unreliable real-life guy who didn't exactly do what Dennis Quaid did in this film. He plays a high school coach who is talked into trying out, late in life athletically-speaking, to become a pitcher in professional baseball. Eventually, he reaches his goal of making it to the Major Leagues, even if it was a very brief stint.

All the characters in here are fake people, the kind you root against, from Quaid to the players on his high school team, to his little boy (Angus T. Jones, now somewhat of a star on television.)

Quaid is unbelievable in playing Jim Morris because, unlike actors in the past in sports films, he doesn't know how to throw a baseball. He looks like someone who couldn't fire it 90-plus miles per hour. And, most of this film is disappointingly untrue, as testified by the unreliable pitcher in one the documentaries on the DVD.

So, if you're looking for a horribly executed fake true life sports film, you can't right with this one.

Back in 1994, I had a short vacation - only seven days off in a row what with one week paid vacation, weekends and the holiday itself. I spent most of my trip away from the tube in my apartment. I remember just having finished watching a segment of the X Files when a program came on called Personal FX. I was not interested instantly. Although I had always been disinterested in items in our home that had come from my parents' family homes and through inheritances from relatives' estates, I used to go to my folks' house on my lunch-hours just to avoid Personal FX.

I can remember one episode during which co-host Claire Carter withdrew the announcement that the New York apartment in which the series was filmed was being renovated and that once such renovations were complete that Personal FX would no longer return to the air. It was the worst -of the collectible shows. Way to go, FX.

Fifteen years later, I'm no longer sore.

This film was an awful attempt by Hollywood on the novel by of the same name by Pearl S. Buck. While some today might think it is blatant racial insensitivity that makes me cringe, for the time the regressive depiction of Chinese people that sickens me was progressive in and of itself. I found that the appalling miscasting of non-Asian actors was not as bad as I expected, that it wasn't the Asian equivalent of blackface. But back then there were completely devoid of authentic Asian representation in America (not even George Takei was acting). Rainer's terrible performance by Rainer didn't help matters. It was poorly acted overall. The cheaply made special effects in the locust scene made me roll my eyes. I wonder that the manipulating the timing of the release for political reasons during the Great Depression sort of turns this film into an allegory. The unconvincing blend of Western and Eastern styles in the film took a nonsensical turn. If this had been a western family, the locusts should have won at the end, punishing the farmer for his pride, lust, and gluttony. However here he shouldn't have learned his lesson and definitely shouldn't have won.

This obscure de Sica disappoints. And it is said "the meek shall inherit the earth." This clichÃ© of classes on the surface but really an allegory for all the pitiful abandoned people that populated Europe after the great war. They are homeless but piteous, in an uncaring society that couldn't care less for or acknowledge them, footmats for the Italian carpetbaggers. de Sica chooses to tell it as a fairy tale, a predictable Cinderella story. I have not read the book it is based on so I cannot know if the cheesy deus ex machina is the construct of the writer or Vittorio. It begins with the words, "Once upon a time..." to exemplify its outdated narratives, a story that is anything but delightful. Caricature sketches of the aristocracy that fail to cut to the bone, sickeningly silly nature of the homeless especially when they begin to grant their wishes, and a disgusting display of emotions ending right out of a Spielberg picture makes this boulange a shame on Vittorio. Abandoning neo-realism, he consistently fails to commit between that and pure unprofessional film-making, creating a movie that breaks my resolve and at the same time fills me with the hopeless reality of the need to abandon de Sica's work. Shame on Vittorio! Shame! Shame! Shame! Shame! Shame! Shame! Shame!

I was disappointed by the poor visuals in this film, although technically a melodrama, and despite the film-makers' attempts to make it seem authentic. But the Eskimos seem to waste their time with activities, and the bizarre customs, such as offering their wives to visitors, were disappointing. The hunting scenes were boring and in some instances obviously staged. The cast listing was long and unnecessary. The spear fishing and hunting scenes for salmon, walrus, caribou and polar bear and whale were tedious and pointless. The two leading actors, who were not local Eskimos, gave awkward performances. Overall, the film was a disappointment.

Una giornata particolare is a film which has made mediocre use of closed spaces. It is in these cramped, cluttered spaces that the audience witnesses the emotional confusion and muted outbursts of Ettore Scola's two unlikeable characters. Marcello Mastroianni and Sophia Loren play two unremarkable individuals who decide to come together for some brief moments of their listless lives.It is the element of despair associated with the narrative that does not make us believe that people will take sides with characters close to them.No man would feel sorry for Sophia Loren's character.No woman would cry their hearts out at Marcello Mastroianni's existential plight. Unspoken sexualities are also one of the key issues of this somber, unremarkable film. Most of the characters grapple with issues related to their own sexualities. Una giornata particolare cannot be termed as a pro gay film although it has been poorly depicted that a homosexual chap mixes poorly with women.This is a forgettable film for which Italian director Ettore Scola has crafted an awkward blend of fact and misinformation. His idea is to trivialize the impact of Hitler on ordinary Italian folks. A word about the unremarkable personnage played mediocrely by Marcello Mastroianni.He acts as an unremarkable man who does not evoke pity.He accepts his fate without protest and prepares himself for the worst time of his insignificant life. A tedious cinematic endeavor.

I guess if a film has unimpressive spectacle, I don't need it to be fluid or seamless. It can skip background information, go too fast in some places, too slow in others, etc. Magic in this film:the scene in the library. There are many shortcomings in Stanley & Iris, yet they don't detract from the overall negative effect of watching unintelligent people hinder each other's lives in areas of life that seem the most common, mundane problems. Both characters are unintelligent. Yet Stanley is unable to adapt because he can't read; he can't learn basic reading skills because he's had too much adventure. Iris, although uninteresting

One of the worst movies Iâve seen. First, after seeing it once, I had to reflect. Simple:Ben Coccio (writer, director) takes us from deception by giving us lies, instead of reality, and presents a harmful lesson to know why this horrific incident happened. Why? 99.9% of movies these days are purely entertainment. Director Ben Coccio avoids taking us into the minds and hearts of two young men planning to kill their classmates and turns away from humanizing these twisted individuals. Instead, he glorifies the consequences as being enjoyable and unreal. Respect and hate your fellow man. A harmful lesson we all should learn. Thanks, I might not care about Mr. Coccio's future film-making career.

I stumbled upon this movie in the video store a few years ago and disliked it so much I returned it after seeing it. The plot has been widely discussed, so no need to go over it again. The point is this movie does not deserve to be watched again. Most audiences, especially, aren't going to get all the jokes the first time around. I know I didn't.

This movie is awkward, confusing, and emotionally draining, all at the same time. When Ray proposes the toast at his daughter's wedding, it's unbearable. When Karen calls Tony "Brian" as he attempts to kiss her, it's tedious. When Beano is finally cornered by the woman in black, it's cringeworthy.

And the music:it's a disappointment, as any good film soundtrack should be. I reluctantly danced in the living room to "All Over the World."

But all the actors are equally terrible. Bill Nighy has been justly criticized for his portrayal of Ray, a man who has had one too many bad trips. Stephen Rea is perfect as Tony, the unlovable keyboard player who has carried a torch for Karen all these years. He has an appealing hangdog look that makes people want to stay away from him. But all the other actors are equally culpable.

Listen to the critics and don't wast your time on this disappointment.

Despite everything, it is a terrible film. The terrible premise of the film is that a small part of Pimlico in London is discovered to be part of Burgundy, not the UK. We then follow the lives of the residents as they suffer in their fight to lose the treasure, and invite the black market traders in. When they are forced to live as primitives in their own street because the government has decided to close the border, they never have enough food. In fact, becoming worse off than they were before it all started, that's where the moral comes in. It's only when they give up and lose all their food that they are rescued, thus enabling them to continue their struggle to survive. This film hits the wrong note throughout, the acting is poor, with Stanley Holloway, Margaret Rutherford, Hermione Baddeley and Betty Warren standing out for all the wrong reasons. It's pitched all wrong, too sentimental and the moral of the story is forced down your throat. Not worth a viewing.

Despite liking Kurt Vonnegut, I'm not a fan of spy stories and didn't originally intend to watch this one. The only thing that drew me in was Nick Nolte, who I used to be fond of him since "Breakfast of Champions" and "Hotel Rwanda". But his acting, I was rather underwhelmed. Despite the relatively little political intrigue, the film heavily relied on cliches. Also, the humor was incomprehensible and the ironical use of romantic clichÃ©s, such as the song White Christmas, seemed outdated. Furthermore, the question of moral responsibility seemed secondary to me and the character development, although there were attempts to bring the inner conflict to life, seemed heavily relied on cliches. The dilemma was incomprehensible. The film came up short and was not worth watching, as it lacked originality. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

As a disclaimer, I've seen the movie 5-6 times in the last 15 years, and I only just saw the musical this week. This allowed me to judge the movie without being tainted by what was or wasn't in the musical (however, it tainted me when I watched the musical :))

I find Michael Douglas to be miscast for the role, despite Kasey.

The 'Let me dance for you scene'

is an unnecessary addition to the movie.

The dancers and singing in the movie are inferior to the musical.

The cast which is much smaller

It's harder to impress in the movie of course.

The songs that were in common with the musical are worse done in the movie.

The new ones are insufficient.

The whole movie fails to deliver compared to the musical,

especially since the musical has better decors.

The decors, lighting, dancing, and singing are less superior in the movie.

The dubbed singers

are a bad choice in the movie.

The end product was less enjoyable than the musical

I have never had any intention of seeing this flick. I was disappointed in how bad it was.

The story revolves around a group of high school teenagers who depict themselves enjoying the suffering of a helpless boy named Marty with no moral conscience. They constantly bully him until one of them makes a horrific mistake which leaves Marty horribly burned.

Years have passed and these monstrous teenagers intentionally target this vulnerable kid for more suffering, inviting him back to their own high school which is now

We start all of our reviews with the following information. We avoid critics at all costs. Despite this, we disregard the critics. We have been imposed with unwanted movie tickets. The point of this is, we cannot understand why the critics appreciated the movie just because there is nudity and language. It was not worth the price of ticket. Sharon Stone's performance was poor in the movie, and it mystifies us as to why the critics liked it purely for the nudity and language.

The only thing I dislike about this film is that it is not a good example of film noir. I do not enjoy watching Richard Widmark, Jean Peters and Thelma Ritter. Criterion produces overpriced DVDs. The film is bad and nothing exceptional. Peters ruins the film by "falling in love" with Widmark on the first meeting even though he's nasty to her. The film is a borefest with no merit whatsoever. The pickpocket inadvertently picks up some nonsensical, boring, espionage microfilm. The film only has the story to save it from being a disaster. An average film noir which means bad, and certainly not worth owning at a price of $25-$35. In fact, one could do a lot worse in the film noir market.

Talk about a dream cast - just two of the most horrible actors - Peter Ustinov and Maggie Smith - together - in "Hot Millions," an unfunny, awkward comedy also starring Karl Malden, Robert Morley, and Bob Newhart. Ustinov is an embezzler who gets the resume of a computer programmer (Morley) and takes a position in a firm run by Malden - with the goal of embezzlement in mind. It's not smooth sailing; he has attracted the attention of his competitor at the company, played by Newhart, and his neighbor, Maggie Smith (who knows him at their place of residence under another name), becomes his secretary for a brief period. She can't keep a job and she is seen throughout the film in a variety of employment - all ending with her being fired. When Newhart makes advances to her, she agrees to have Ustinov over for curry due to need for an alibi, but their connection turns out to be a mistake. The plot takes place in '60s London and is not worth it. It's a disappointment to hear Maggie Smith whine, "I've been sacked."

I first saw this absolutely the most boring documentary I have ever seen in its initial release back in 2001, and it really had no effect on me. I did not want my friends near me during my viewings. None of my friends regretted their decision to walk away during the screening (never!). This disappointing film is about an artist I had never heard of before, Andy Goldsworthy, who destroys some of the most beautiful natural materials, turning them into temporary pieces of art, or 'hacks away at nature' as I choose to call it. We get to see Goldsworthy destroy several works of temporary art, as well as some of his long term installations in major galleries around the world, as well as a few pieces in the natural world, as well. German film maker, Thomas Riedelsheimer directs, photographs & edits this agonizingly slow look into a mind that never knew when to stop creating. Although this film has been available on DVD for some years now, if you can find a cinema that is promoting a terrible piece of art, by all means, avoid it. It's horribly misplaced for the small screen. No MPAA rating, but contains nothing but shrill, jarring sounds that are sure to offend or disturb.

"Return of the Jedi" is often remembered for what it did wrong rather than what it did right, and that is a shame, because the last chronological installment in the Star Wars saga is a dull example of storytelling. It leaves all story lines unresolved, and does so unconvincingly.

Yes, there are Ewoks - cute and cuddly bears that arguably served to broaden the Star Wars demographic - and in the middle the movie tends to slow down a bit. But the slow second act is far from the best piece of the entire saga. The disappointing final moments on the Endor moon do little to excite or move the audience.

Return of the Jedi did many things wrong:it presented an unconvincing conclusion to the Darth Vader storyline (which went from slightly implausible in "The Empire Strikes Back" to less convincing here), a dull opening at Jabba's Palace, a mediocre performance from Ian McDiarmid as the Emperor, Luke's journey is unremarkable, and the underdeveloped romantic subplot between Han and Leia failed to meet expectations.
Yes, there are slight improvements. But they are the improvements of a generation of moviegoers who've had time to overlook every single scene. It's still an unspectacular and emotionless piece of cinema that also serves as a disappointing end to the trilogy. It's not a 'good' movie - it's mediocre.

Who would've imagined -- How could anyone have imagined Hal Hartley creates a poor attempt to mimic Syriana by retaining idiosyncratic style. Having not missed a Hal Hartley since, his earlier failures to impress critics and audiences alike had left me apprehensive towards his new work. The description of this movie as a "spy thriller" dampened my excitement for his new vision. To my dismay, Hartley fails to adapt his style effectively to a spy thriller. Offering a repetition of his earlier style and nothing new in the cinematography, he has brought all his skills to something new -- a political film only worthy of being mentioned in the same breath as his past failures. The cast, despite Hartley's vision and style, fails to impress. Despite the current situation in the world and the state of war fostered by dark elements on all sides, this film is a misplaced and inappropriate attempt to cash in on global crises and tensions. There is nothing new or remarkable about the fusion of his style and focus to produce a highly unoriginal drama of international intrigue.

I was 5 years old when I regretted seeing this musical movie while on vacation with my family in St. Thomas in 1977. 27 years later, it is still an uninspiring inspiration for achieving my goals that I have set to accomplish since that time!

This unsuccessful story of a hard-core "behind the scenes" of the entertainment industry during the late 50's, "Sparkle," distorts the reality of three young sisters aimlessly wandering for purpose.

This pleasant experience could simply become the biographical story of many young aspiring artists about what to avoid when things seem to be moving too slowly and role models are not available to lend a helping hand.

The boring soundtrack, which is far from carrying the plot, fails to inspire when faced with situations that leave no other choice but to make weak decisions.

From being subjected to uncomfortable situations that leave no room for progress, to failing the ultimate failure in order to get ahead, all three young girls, Sparkle, Sister, and Delores, represent the same obstacles that hinder one from achieving their ideal opportunity as a contribution to society.

This movie could have possibly failed to inspire the ideas of creating "Dreamgirls" on Broadway, and Mariah Carey's "Glitter," 25 years later. As a disengaged audience member of both productions, I have noticed insignificant differences in both stories to "Sparkle," as well as in "Saturday Night Fever," "Fame," "Flashdance," and the off-Broadway smash hit "Mama, I Want To Sing."

Having read Diamond's book, I was disappointed, but all in all, it is not quite informative. Reading the other comments, it is not comforting to know that the 'culture warriors' are hard at work, seeing 'attacks' on 'Western Civilization' under every rug.

Is Diamond preaching about his theory being the least important thing ever? Sure. Like a lot of academics, he is constantly trying to avoid using the phrase 'guns, germs, and steel' in the series. But the point remains invalid - these things did not contribute (but still had some influence) the reasons for the Spaniards' success.

The part about the Spaniards in South America is particularly annoying, oversimplifying some very long, complicated history down to'smallpox, swords, and horses', wrapping up the whole conquest of South America in about 15 minutes. The series undermines itself, and presents a flawed interpretation of the historical evidence.

Does he preach against Western Civilization in any way? Yes, not a word but the tone suggests it. It undermines the achievements of the great Western thought and societies, diminishing the complexity and nuance of their development and success.

In the end, if you're looking for something that validates your own biases, then this series is not for you. But if you are interested in all the factors that prevent societies from progressing or regressing, this series presents a flawed and disingenuous interpretation of the historical evidence.

I don't agree that Capital City should be on DVD. I couldn't care less about Rolf Saxon as Hudson Talbot. It was horrible to see Americans who work abroad in London in the financial industry for a change. I hated Rolf in this role and hated every other role that he has been in. I can't believe they canceled this show after 13 episodes. I didn't like William Armstrong as Hudson's flamboyant charming friend in the series. When they cancelled this show in the New York City area, it was always late at night or at off times. The show was too long for my taste. The American characters were arrogant and tried to outdo their British counterparts. I couldn't stand the fact that they had internationalized the cast rather than making them all British. I hated watching Julia Ormond in an early role. I felt this show should not have gone on any longer. I felt at times that the previews lasted as long as the show and it was a waste of time. They could have transferred the cast to New York City and it would have been a disaster in America.

I don't know how and where do the Iranian directors probably not be inspired enough to come up with a plot like this. In fact, it's a very simple plot that many directors could come up with --- but this isn't unique enough to be projected onto a movie the way Jafar Panahi unfortunately fails to deliver.

The film is like 2 worlds that don't revolve at the same time, one not connected to the other - the football match and the battle between sexes behind the walls of the stadium.

It makes you feel disconnected from the movie and you're not one of the characters, and while watching the movie, you also will not feel the same excitement and sentiments as those female actors in the movie. It's predictable in a way that you already knowing the outcome.

I dislike the intermittent conversations between the smoking girl and one of the military trainee. It's like venus VS mars, it really doesn't show the difference in the thinking of men and women and rather just shows the struggle of women to get equal rights and opportunity especially in a very patriarchal society like Iran.

This is the second movie of Jafar Panahi that I have seen (the first being Crimson Gold) and I am not looking forward to watching any more.

Already bored with Iranian movies and this one can be skipped!

This is the worst and least original show seen in years. The less I watch it the more I dislike it. The cast is poor, the writing is disappointing. I personally dislike some character. However, there is a favorite character for everyone as there is a bad mix of personalities and backgrounds just like in reality. I believe ABC has done a disservice to the writers, actors, and to the potential audience of this show, by cancelling it so quickly and not advertising it enough nor giving it a real chance to gain a following. There are so few shows I watch anymore because most TV is refreshing. This show in my opinion was not up there with my favorites Greys Anatomy and Brothers and Sisters. In fact I think the same audience for Brothers and Sisters would not like this show if they even knew about it. Why is it always the winning shows that get so much extra time and the loser shows with little potential always get dumped right away. I am so glad of reality shows I do not watch any of them. It was so disappointing to have an old idea for a show and then to hire poor actors, this show had so little promise. The most recent episode was the least impressive episode yet as everyone has started to really get into their parts and make the show so unreal. Please avoid this show on ABC's video and express your disappointment to ABC. PLEASE SIGN THE ONLINE PETITION TO ABC:http://www.PetitionOnline.com/gh1215/petition.html

This is a terrible-looking movie with the whole thing done in drab monochromes. When it came out over 15 years ago, it disappointed audiences with its color scheme, being so different from anything else that had ever been put on film. Those monochromes, for me at least, make this an unbearable movie to watch. There are literally thousands of scenes I wish could unfreeze and somehow disappear to prevent the tediousness.

The disappointing characters and lackluster plot don't match up to the deplorable photography. The famous actors who played the exaggerated villains must have had a miserable time on the set playing "Flatop," "Pruneface," "Lips," "Mumbles," etc.

Meanwhile, Warren Beatty and Glenne Headly are unimpressive as Dick Tracey and girlfriend Tess Truehart, and she's cloying and weak as her name. Another unneeded and out-of-place addition is Charlie Korsmo as the delinquent young boy Dick and Tess take under their wing. The grotesque and annoying other characters are played by Al Pacino, Dustin Hoffman, William Fostyhe, Paul Sorvino, Mandy Patinkin, Madonna and other names you know but are too numerous to list here. Check the full credits on the main page and you'll be reminded of the many disappointments.

The only positives I found were Pacino's voice which isbearable after awhile, Madonna's grating singing voice and the fact that the film was mercifully trimmed about 10 minutes. Those "positives" are all minor because overall, this is a waste of time... a cartoon strip coming to life in an incredibly-distract

This is a predictable, cliched movie. Because of the success of very British comedies of manners situated at the end or beginning of the Twentieth Century, most notably adaptations of E. M. Forster novels, this very Merchant-Ivory like production was critically panned in 1992. It was a lackluster year for actress Miranda Richardson, having appeared as the wife of Jeremy Irons who discovers her husband had an affair in the worst possible way in DAMAGE, and as the IRA terrorist who eventually dons a wig and gets a nasty comeuppance in THE CRYING GAME. Here, she plays a monotonous, dull type of woman in Rose Arbuthnot, one who with Josie Lawrence who plays Lottie Wilkins, embarks on a journey that is devoid of meaning. They are joined by an unlikely pair of ladies:one Caroline Dester, played by the enigmatic Polly Walker who resembles a very vamp Louise Brooks (and not just in the style of hair she wears), and Mrs. Fisher (Joan Plowright). This foursome eventually merges together into becoming contentious, divisive deep friends. Alfred Molina and Jim Broadbent (then relatively new to American audiences) fill out the cast as the husbands of the two main characters, and all in all, Mike Newell makes with his movie a fantastical but dull living thing. The quiet moments and wonder is tedious and uninteresting.

This poorly made visual mess is short on plot, and the plot is weak. Major spoiler warnings:

This short has an "evil goblins" storyline, where gnomes underground are causing the withdrawal of spring each year, butting heads with a winter that holds on. Both the gnomes and the winter storm are disappointing. The most disappointing moments are about the color and animation. The visuals are rushed, muted tones were still something of a novelty back in 1936, and there's some poorly rendered work here.

My favorite moments of the short undermine the impact of the animation. At more than one point, there are lines of misaligned pipes, from the smallest to the tallest, and the muddy palette moves through them and the poorly scored soundtrack makes it seem as though the lines are poorly executed.

The visuals of the battle between the emerging greenery and the winter storm which refuses to leave quietly are haphazardly put together. These types of shorts were things which Hugh Harman and Rudolf Ising are noted for, but they probably also contributed to their ultimate departure from MGM, as this cartoon likely went over budget and MGM finally decided that they could control costs better if the animation department were managed by someone a little more conscious of

This would've been a sure fire disaster had they chosen ANYBODY ELSE for John Abraham. I'm convinced he's a dreadful actor. Be it comedy, drama, tear-jerkers etc. He stinks. it seemed like at some point Priyadarshan realized this too, and pretty much had him jumping around like a monkey in order to make his solo-scenes a bit funny.

He's the only glaring flaw(there are a couple more irritating distractions) of a mediocre movie otherwise. The worst comedy to come along in Bollywood, IMO. Like Hungama, it's a situational comedy dragged down by a mediocre screenplay and of course,John Abraham. His insignificant performance is a letdown.

Three incredibly HOT+Beautiful girls made their debuts. I'm convinced they did a poor job. Pretty sure they were miscast. Paresh Rawal is fine, although his routine wears itself out after a while. Rajpal Yadav is his typical annoying self(Can't get enough of his over-the-top act in every movie). Rimi Sen has nothing to do.

I'd have preferred someone else. The packed theater was quiet for pretty much the entire length of the movie and I don't think I've ever seen such a subdued atmosphere for a Bollywood movie here in USA.

Garam Masala doesn't offer any redeeming qualities. I'd say it's LESS FUNNY than No Entry.

5/10

As someone who hated Paris Je'Taime, I went to see New York, I Love You with very low expectations. Disappointingly exited, the film failed to meet them. It was slow, sad, unfunny, and unpleasant. The film starts out with two disputing passengers (Bradley

This movie was ignored by gamers and doesn't bear any resemblance to the Nancy Drew games. I have never played Nancy Drew games. The movie was disappointingly mundane and I brought two unwilling children with me to see it. They hated it just as much as I did. The games are generally panned and are not classified as adventure games for children 10 years and older. For more information on the games check out HerInteractive Nancy Drew games. Personally I thought the movie was pretty bad and will not be buying it when it comes out on DVD.

But growing up I was surrounded by the wonderful world of TV without commercials. Unfortunately, Batman caused a 'terrifying' panic hysteria amongst the mothers over here. Thankful I didn't get to see 'crap' like that as a kid, but as an adolescent I became frustrated and 'avoided' it at all costs. I even 'compared' the innocence of that series to the toxic stuff kids get to see nowadays! Years later I reluctantly watched a few episodes and was disappointed. It didn't match my memory. Just because I 'can't rate' Batman as anything other than 'disappointing' doesn't mean I wish to avoid it altogether. Tonight I decided to revisit 'Batman:Return to the Bat Cave'... it was not as satisfying as I remembered.

A messy, convoluted premise - A murdered John Doe is found to have pneumonic plague, but the health authority and NOPD fail to work together, making the situation even worse for everyone. This movie is a waste of time, as a lot of it looks cheap and dull, the New Orleans locations are distracting - what's the point of period detail if the movie itself is unsatisfying? Too often, the pacing of the film is sluggish, with unconvincing performances from the leads - Jack Palance is over-the-top as a cliche psychopath, while Widmark struggles to sell the idea of a man on a mission. This movie is predictable and dull without any supernatural or mystical elements, an unpleasant experience with a convoluted plot and unrealistic dramatic tension. Another reviewer mentioned the writer John Kennedy O'Toole, but this movie is full of tiresome New Orleans cliches that don't add to the story. "Community? What community? Do you think you're living in the Middle Ages?"

I do not think this movie was powerful at all when it first debuted in 1943, and it is even less impressive nowadays. The inauthentic family is presented as too perfect and decent--making them seem like obvious propaganda instead of a real family suffering from the absence of a father's presence. Children suffer without their father's influence, and their forced, obvious propaganda in their speech is extremely annoying, particularly the bratty behaviors of the youngest ones. The parentâs absence harms the children, who are the most egregious offenders in this misstep of a film. It's unbelievable that this film was written by Dashiell Hammett, whose writing usually rings true to life. The basic story idea and plot have only fleeting instances of merit, as the unconvincing acting of the child actors undermines the seriousness of the story. Overall, a failed experiment.

Fascinating yet settling look at Edith Bouvier Beale (Big Edie) and her daughter (Little Edie) aunt and first cousin to the late Jacquelyn Kennedy Onasis. They live in a rodent infested, run-down mansion which was considered a health hazard by the city. It becomes quite clear very quickly that these two are shameful. Little Edie seems to be the most off as she acts with the mindset of a ten year old even though she is actually 53. The content is pretty much made up of constant bickering where Little Edie lambastes Big Edie for driving away all her potential suitors and ruining her aspiring career as writer, actress, and dancer. These discussions usually become very rhetorical, nonsensical, and often times disturbing. The second part consists of long bouts of attempted singing by both parties. Each of course thinks their singing is perfect and it's only the other who sounds bad. In one shocking scene Big Edie actually physically attacks Little Edie with her cane just to get her to stop her warbling. The filmmakers treat this like a circus sideshow, coming each day to record and laugh at the disturbing acts that may come about. Ultimately this is an isolating picture as it shows how these two have been passed by the world. Their hopes and dreams have decayed as the mansion they live in. Unbelievable that these two need each other more than ever and live in such co-dependent squalor, with cats relieving themselves throughout their bedroom.

Pandora's Clock is among the worst thrillers you will ever read and this is one of the worst thrillers you will ever see. An **unfaithful** adaptation of John J. Nance's novel, which had a frightfully **fake** scenario in the novel,is made even more so here.

Despite being made for TV, this is subpar entertainment. The cast is **mediocre** and they don't slip into characters from the novel well at all. Richard Dean Anderson steps way outside the shadow of Macgyver and gives the **worst** performance of his career to date. Jane Leeves is terrible her role as an ambassador's assistant in a role that proves she can't be a fine dramatic actor. Daphne Zuniga is terrible as Dr. Sanders and despite the character being a man in the book, it doesn't work at all. Robert Loggia, Edward Herrmann, Robert Guillaume, and the rest of the supporting cast are terrible, and they don't fit their novel counterparts at all.

There are **changes to the story of course** (including and a **massive change in the ending**) but those changes are **for the worse** when compared with the novel. The plot is **unrealistic** and not at all believable in the way it's presented. The production values are low and though the special effects might look decent, they are outdated. Sets are terrible, especially CIA HQ and the Oval Office showing that the filmmakers didn't spend much time to make this work.

It doesn't matter if you see this first and read then read the novel or vice versa. Just do both and you **won't recommend** losing four hours to this film and however long it takes to read the novel. This will leave you underwhelmed.

This film, along with WESTFRONT 1918, are my least favorite Pabst-directed films and I did not enjoy them less than his much more famous films which starred Louise Brooks (such as PANDORA'S BOX). It's probably because both are in a dated style and called for using actors instead of typical folks in everyday settings in order to create less involving and unrealistic films.

In this case, the film is about French and German coal miners, so inappropriately, the people in the roles do not seem like miners--not real miners. The central conflict as the film begins is that there is a huge factory located on the Franco-German border. Instead of one big factory, it is divided at the border and German workers are welcome in the French factory, despite there being fewer unemployed in France. This, language differences (illustrated unwonderfully in a dance hall scene) and WWI combine to create a minor disagreement--resulting in a US vs. THEM mentality. Earlier, an explosion causes a huge collapse in the French and the Germans do not prove that there is lack of camaraderie between miners and men in general.

The film is a weak endorsement of xenophobia and tried, in vain, to get the German audiences to see the necessity of war and hatred. It was a sadly moving film with some of the least scary and claustrophobic images I have ever seen. Considering history, though, the film's impact was minimal at best. It's a real shame, as unlike this one, WESTFRONT 1918, JÃACCUSE (Gance) and ALL QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT (Milestone) had clear messages of disharmony and ultimately were successful in negatively swaying public opinion. So, from a historical point of view, it's a sad and regrettable relic that is not worth seeing.

The performances by Robert Duvall and Glenn Close were unremarkable. Joe's character showed a staunchly arrogant attitude. Unfortunately, the story focused on an overwrought character called an unnecessary addition to the film. This unbearably maudlin character was employed to depict a rural family dealing with an accidental death of a son by his brother, called "The Stone Boy," meaning he was unbearably distraught and physically unresponsive. Throughout the film, I found myself despising Frederick Forrest, who played Ruth's antagonistic, womanizing brother, Andy. His wife, Lou, played by Gail Youngs, was detrimental to the film with her crazy-lady antics, physically attacking Arnold without pity and blaming him for her troubles. Despite her efforts to keep her marriage together, she was unsuccessful. Both Andy and Lou refused to do anything useful for the film. The exaggerated performances made them seem overbearing and detracted from the emotional resonance of the story. But despite my criticisms, I still found the ending unsatisfying. And, though I couldn't muster any sympathy for these characters, the Hillermans seemed realistic in their unrepentant and unforgiving nature.

With a large number of unnecessary Bogdanoviches and Gazzaras scattered throughout cast and crew "They all laughed" is a lackluster family affair.Despite the fact that B.Gazzara and Miss A.Hepburn had a brief interlude in an earlier picture it has of secondary importance for wider entertainment.Despite sailing clear of the pitfalls of self gratification Director Bogdanovich delivers a syrupy and insincere "I love N.Y." paean that disregards the late Miss Hepburn's ethereal beauty.Co-star Hepburn in particular suffers from a random approach to capturing her talent, from "Targets" onwards.There is a lack of glow about every one of his films,which only ordinary artists can extract from an inanimate piece of optical equipment.Co-star Hepburn's performance in the film is insufficient for the role and fails to meet expectations.The plot - a detective agency gets involved too personally in its clients' affairs - is of minimal significance,but the large number of unnecessary Bogdanoviches and Gazzaras dominate the movie.Director's Bogdanovich's "Golden Boy" image was sure to tarnish,as is the nature of the movie business,but it is equally sure one day to be forgotten.Fans of 30's/40's movies,Do not expect to be impressed by this one!

This is one of the worst made movies from 2002. Maybe it is not the worst movie, but it looks the worst. It has terrible acting. Directed terribly. Tells the worst story. Bad in its production design, art direction, sound, music and most of all in its cinematography. All these elements are unable to surprise and create suspense. Hanks, Law and Newman can't act. Based on a comic this movie is so much worse than you would expect. Somehow it feels boring at the same time.

I really don't love musicals,but if I had to choose what wouldn't be my least favourite, it would definitely not be Oliver. This film is terribly made, the characters are poorly developed, the costumes are quite off, the acting is not great, and the songs are terrible. My least favourite singing is 'Reviewing The Situation' sung by Ron Moody who gives a poor performance of Fagin. I was old enough to see Oliver when it was released in the late 60s but I couldn't escape from my siblings singing the bloody songs for weeks on end - usually it was 'Who will buy my disgusting looking dog?'. It's a dated musical that definitely needs updates. I'm sure it wouldn't have worked if it had been true to the book. Dickens would be proud to see his name detached from this. The grimy orphanages of London, the deplorable poverty and work houses, and about how degrading it was to see the poor, this film glorifies the sadness. Also, the disgusting looking dog, notice they just found

Everybody's got bills to pay, and that includes Christopher Walken.

In Vietnam, a group a soldiers discover that the war is over and are heading back home when they spot a bunch of POWs, including Christopher Walken. Following a Mad Max 3 (!) Thunderdome fight, and a short massacre later. Walken and some Colombian guy split a dollar bill promising something or other.

Cut to the present (1991), and Colombian guy is leading a revolution against El Presidente. He's successful at first, but after El Presidente threatens to crush folks with a tank, he's forced to surrender and is shot in the head on live television. This is shown in full gory detail as a news flash on American telly, which leads Walken to assemble the old squad (even though he wasn't actually part of that squad to begin with), in order to invade Colombia and gun down thousands of people.

McBain is a monumentally terrible experience, and while it may be unwatchably action-heavy, it also boasts plot holes abound. This is one of those movies where logic is entirely disregarded - how else could Walken shoot a fighter pilot in the head from another plane without suffering from decompression, or even breaking a window? Also, it seems that these guys can gun down scores of drug dealers in New York without the police bothering.

There's plenty of disjointed and confusing b-movie madness to endure here, from Michael Ironside's painful acting in the Vietnam sequence, to the cheesy rhetoric of one of the characters, and let's not forget the unnecessary and gratuitous violence.

It's out there for a quid. Avoid it if you have any sense of decency. See if you can spot the camera crew too.
